ch_gram_a1_01.title: Gender of Nouns
ch_gram_a1_01.theory:
## Masculine and Feminine Nouns

Every Spanish noun is either **masculine** or **feminine**. There is no neutral gender.

### Basic Rules
- Nouns ending in **-o** are usually masculine: el libr**o**, el gat**o**
- Nouns ending in **-a** are usually feminine: la cas**a**, la mes**a**

### Common Exceptions
- **el día** (the day) — masculine despite ending in -a
- **el mapa** (the map) — masculine
- **la mano** (the hand) — feminine despite ending in -o
- **el problema** (the problem) — masculine (Greek-origin words ending in -ma)

### Other Endings
| Ending | Gender | Examples |
|--------|--------|----------|
| -ción, -sión | Feminine | la nación, la televisión |
| -dad, -tad | Feminine | la ciudad, la libertad |
| -or | Masculine | el color, el amor |
| -aje | Masculine | el viaje, el paisaje |
key_points: All Spanish nouns have a gender: masculine or feminine
-o ending → usually masculine, -a ending → usually feminine
Memorize common exceptions: el día, el mapa, la mano
Words ending in -ción/-sión/-dad are feminine

ch_gram_a1_02.title: Definite Articles
ch_gram_a1_02.theory:
## Definite Articles (el, la, los, las)

Spanish has four definite articles, equivalent to English "the".

| | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | **el** | **los** |
| Feminine | **la** | **las** |

### Usage
- **el libro** → the book / **los libros** → the books
- **la casa** → the house / **las casas** → the houses

### When to Use Definite Articles
- Talking about something specific: **El perro** es grande. (The dog is big.)
- General statements: **Los gatos** son independientes. (Cats are independent.)
- Days of the week: Trabajo **el lunes**. (I work on Monday.)
- Languages (after hablar, omit): Hablo español. BUT: **El** español es fácil.

### Contraction Rules
- **a + el = al**: Voy **al** parque. (I go to the park.)
- **de + el = del**: Vengo **del** cine. (I come from the cinema.)
key_points: Four forms: el (m.sg), la (f.sg), los (m.pl), las (f.pl)
Used for specific things AND general statements
Contractions: a + el = al, de + el = del
Used with days of the week: el lunes, los martes

ch_gram_a1_03.title: Indefinite Articles
ch_gram_a1_03.theory:
## Indefinite Articles (un, una, unos, unas)

Spanish indefinite articles correspond to English "a/an" (singular) and "some" (plural).

| | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | **un** | **unos** |
| Feminine | **una** | **unas** |

### Examples
- **un** libro → a book / **unos** libros → some books
- **una** casa → a house / **unas** casas → some houses

### When NOT to Use Indefinite Articles
Unlike English, Spanish omits the indefinite article with:
- Professions: Soy **profesor**. (I am a teacher.) — NOT *Soy un profesor.*
- Nationality: Es **española**. (She is Spanish.)
- After *sin* (without): Café **sin** azúcar. (Coffee without sugar.)
- After negative *no hay*: No hay **problema**. (There is no problem.)

### Indefinite vs Definite
- **Un** gato está en la calle. → A cat is in the street. (any cat)
- **El** gato está en la calle. → The cat is in the street. (specific cat)
key_points: Four forms: un (m.sg), una (f.sg), unos (m.pl), unas (f.pl)
Omit with professions: Soy profesor (not *Soy un profesor*)
Unos/unas means 'some' or 'approximately'
Use indefinite for first mention, definite for known things

vocab_list.example_meaning: I have a friend in Spain.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Barcelona is a beautiful city.

ch_gram_a1_04.title: Subject Pronouns
ch_gram_a1_04.theory:
## Subject Pronouns

| Person | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| 1st | **yo** (I) | **nosotros/nosotras** (we) |
| 2nd informal | **tú** (you) | **vosotros/vosotras** (you all) |
| 2nd formal | **usted** (you) | **ustedes** (you all) |
| 3rd | **él/ella** (he/she) | **ellos/ellas** (they) |

### Key Points
- **tú** = informal (friends, family) / **usted** = formal (strangers, elders)
- **vosotros** is used mainly in Spain; Latin America uses **ustedes** for both
- **nosotras/vosotras/ellas** = all-female groups

### Subject Pronoun Omission
Spanish often drops the subject pronoun because the verb conjugation shows who is speaking:
- **(Yo) Hablo** español. → I speak Spanish.
- **(Tú) Tienes** un gato. → You have a cat.

Pronouns are used for emphasis or clarity:
- **Yo** hablo español, **ella** habla francés. → I speak Spanish, she speaks French.
key_points: Subject pronouns are often omitted — verb endings indicate the subject
tú (informal) vs usted (formal)
vosotros (Spain only) vs ustedes (universal for plural 'you')
Use pronouns for emphasis or to avoid ambiguity

vocab_list.example_meaning: I am a student.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Do you speak Spanish?

ch_gram_a1_05.title: Verb Ser (Present)
ch_gram_a1_05.theory:
## Ser — Present Tense Conjugation

| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **soy** |
| tú | **eres** |
| él/ella/usted | **es** |
| nosotros/as | **somos** |
| vosotros/as | **sois** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **son** |

### Uses of Ser
1. **Identity**: Yo **soy** María. (I am María.)
2. **Nationality/Origin**: Ella **es** española. (She is Spanish.)
3. **Profession**: Nosotros **somos** profesores. (We are teachers.)
4. **Characteristics**: El libro **es** interesante. (The book is interesting.)
5. **Time/Date**: **Son** las tres. (It is 3 o'clock.) / Hoy **es** lunes. (Today is Monday.)
6. **Material**: La mesa **es** de madera. (The table is made of wood.)

### Memory Tip
**Ser** = permanent/essential traits → who you ARE, not how you FEEL
key_points: Ser is irregular: soy, eres, es, somos, sois, son
Used for identity, nationality, profession, characteristics, time
Ser = permanent/essential qualities
Son las + number for telling time

vocab_list.example_meaning: I am a student.

vocab_list.example: Él es profesor de español.
vocab_list.example_meaning: He is a Spanish teacher.

vocab_list.example: Ella es muy inteligente.
vocab_list.example_meaning: She is very intelligent.

vocab_list.example: Nosotros somos españoles.
vocab_list.example_meaning: We are Spanish.

ch_gram_a1_06.title: Verb Estar (Present)
ch_gram_a1_06.theory:
## Estar — Present Tense Conjugation

| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **estoy** |
| tú | **estás** |
| él/ella/usted | **está** |
| nosotros/as | **estamos** |
| vosotros/as | **estáis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **están** |

### Uses of Estar
1. **Location**: El gato **está** en la mesa. (The cat is on the table.)
2. **Emotions/Feelings**: **Estoy** contento. (I am happy.)
3. **Temporary states**: La sopa **está** caliente. (The soup is hot.)
4. **Health**: ¿Cómo **estás**? — **Estoy** bien. (How are you? — I am fine.)
5. **Progressive tense**: **Estoy** estudiando. (I am studying.)

### Memory Tip
**Estar** = temporary states, locations, emotions → how you FEEL, where you ARE right now
key_points: Estar is irregular: estoy, estás, está, estamos, estáis, están
Used for location, emotions, temporary states, health
Estar = temporary/changeable conditions
¿Cómo estás? is the most common greeting

ch_gram_a1_07.title: Ser vs Estar
ch_gram_a1_07.theory:
## When to Use Ser vs Estar

Both mean "to be" but are used differently.

### Ser — Permanent/Essential
| Use | Example |
|-----|--------|
| Identity | Yo **soy** Ana. |
| Origin | Él **es** de México. |
| Profession | Ella **es** doctora. |
| Characteristics | El edificio **es** alto. |
| Time | **Son** las dos. |

### Estar — Temporary/Changeable
| Use | Example |
|-----|--------|
| Location | El libro **está** en la mesa. |
| Emotions | **Estoy** nervioso. |
| Health | ¿Cómo **estás**? |
| Conditions | La puerta **está** abierta. |
| Progressive | **Estoy** comiendo. |

### Meaning Changes with Ser/Estar
Some adjectives change meaning:
- **ser** aburrido = to be boring / **estar** aburrido = to be bored
- **ser** listo = to be smart / **estar** listo = to be ready
- **ser** malo = to be bad (person) / **estar** malo = to be sick
key_points: Ser = permanent traits (DOCTOR: Description, Origin, Characteristics, Time, Occupation, Relation)
Estar = temporary states (PLACE: Position, Location, Action, Condition, Emotion)
Some adjectives change meaning: ser listo (smart) vs estar listo (ready)
Location always uses estar (except for events: La fiesta es en mi casa)

vocab_list.example: La clase es aburrida. / Estoy aburrido.
vocab_list.example_meaning: The class is boring. / I am bored.

vocab_list.example: Ella es lista. / Ella está lista.
vocab_list.example_meaning: She is smart. / She is ready.

vocab_list.example: La tienda está abierta.
vocab_list.example_meaning: The store is open.

vocab_list.example: Estoy nervioso por el examen.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I am nervous about the exam.

ch_gram_a1_08.title: Adjective Agreement
ch_gram_a1_08.theory:
## Adjective Agreement in Gender and Number

Spanish adjectives must agree with the noun they describe in both gender and number.

### Four Forms of Adjectives (ending in -o)
| | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | alt**o** | alt**os** |
| Feminine | alt**a** | alt**as** |

- El chico es **alto**. → Los chicos son **altos**.
- La chica es **alta**. → Las chicas son **altas**.

### Adjectives Ending in -e or Consonant
These only change for number, NOT gender:
- **grande** → grandes (big)
- **inteligente** → inteligentes (intelligent)
- **fácil** → fáciles (easy)

### Adjective Placement
- Most adjectives go **after** the noun: un libro **interesante**
- Some common adjectives go **before**: **bueno**, **malo**, **grande**, **pequeño**
- **buen/mal** (shortened before masc. sg. nouns): un **buen** libro, un **mal** día
- **gran** (before any sg. noun): una **gran** ciudad (a great city)
key_points: Adjectives ending in -o change to -a/-os/-as to match the noun
Adjectives ending in -e or consonant only change for number
Most adjectives follow the noun: una casa bonita
bueno → buen, malo → mal, grande → gran (before singular nouns)

vocab_list.example_meaning: The building is tall.

vocab_list.example_meaning: The city is pretty.

vocab_list.example_meaning: It is a great idea.

ch_gram_a1_09.title: Regular Verbs -ar (Present)
ch_gram_a1_09.theory:
## -ar Verb Conjugation (Present Tense)

-ar verbs are the most common verb group in Spanish. Remove **-ar** and add the endings:

### Hablar (to speak)
| Person | Stem + Ending |
|---|---|
| yo | habl**o** |
| tú | habl**as** |
| él/ella/usted | habl**a** |
| nosotros/as | habl**amos** |
| vosotros/as | habl**áis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | habl**an** |

### Common -ar Verbs
- **estudiar** (to study): Yo estudi**o** español.
- **trabajar** (to work): Ella trabaj**a** en un banco.
- **comprar** (to buy): Nosotros compr**amos** comida.
- **cocinar** (to cook): Tú cocin**as** muy bien.
- **caminar** (to walk): Ellos camin**an** al parque.

### Pattern
All -ar verbs follow the same endings: **-o, -as, -a, -amos, -áis, -an**
key_points: Remove -ar, add: -o, -as, -a, -amos, -áis, -an
-ar verbs are the largest verb group in Spanish
The stem (before -ar) stays the same for regular verbs
Common verbs: hablar, estudiar, trabajar, comprar, cocinar

vocab_list.example_meaning: I speak Spanish.

vocab_list.example_meaning: She studies medicine.

vocab_list.example: Nosotros trabajamos mucho.
vocab_list.example_meaning: We work a lot.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Do you buy the bread?

ch_gram_a1_10.title: Regular Verbs -er/-ir (Present)
ch_gram_a1_10.theory:
## -er and -ir Verb Conjugation (Present Tense)

### -er Verbs: Comer (to eat)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | com**o** |
| tú | com**es** |
| él/ella/usted | com**e** |
| nosotros/as | com**emos** |
| vosotros/as | com**éis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | com**en** |

### -ir Verbs: Vivir (to live)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | viv**o** |
| tú | viv**es** |
| él/ella/usted | viv**e** |
| nosotros/as | viv**imos** |
| vosotros/as | viv**ís** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | viv**en** |

### -er vs -ir: Almost Identical!
The only differences are in **nosotros** and **vosotros**:
- -er: com**emos**, com**éis**
- -ir: viv**imos**, viv**ís**

All other forms are the same: -o, -es, -e, -en
key_points: -er endings: -o, -es, -e, -emos, -éis, -en
-ir endings: -o, -es, -e, -imos, -ís, -en
Only nosotros/vosotros forms differ between -er and -ir
Common -er: comer, beber, leer / Common -ir: vivir, escribir, abrir

vocab_list.example_meaning: We eat at two o'clock.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I live in Madrid.

ch_gram_a1_11.title: Hay vs Está/Están
ch_gram_a1_11.theory:
## Hay vs Está/Están

### Hay = There is / There are
Used to express **existence** (something exists somewhere).
- **Hay** un gato en el jardín. (There is a cat in the garden.)
- **Hay** muchos libros. (There are many books.)
- ¿**Hay** un banco cerca? (Is there a bank nearby?)

**Hay** is invariable — same form for singular and plural.

### Está/Están = It is / They are (located)
Used to express **location** of something specific.
- El gato **está** en el jardín. (The cat is in the garden.)
- Los libros **están** en la mesa. (The books are on the table.)

### The Key Difference
| | Hay | Está/Están |
|---|---|---|
| Meaning | existence | location |
| Article | indefinite (un/una) | definite (el/la) |
| Number | invariable | agrees (está/están) |

- **Hay un** hospital aquí. → A hospital exists here.
- **El** hospital **está** aquí. → The (specific) hospital is here.
key_points: Hay = existence (there is/are), invariable form
Está/Están = location of specific things
Hay + indefinite article: Hay un libro
Está + definite article: El libro está en la mesa

vocab_list.example: Hay una farmacia en la esquina.
vocab_list.example_meaning: There is a pharmacy on the corner.

vocab_list.example: ¿Hay un banco cerca?
vocab_list.example_meaning: Is there a bank nearby?

vocab_list.example: El aeropuerto está lejos.
vocab_list.example_meaning: The airport is far away.

vocab_list.example: Hay mucha gente aquí.
vocab_list.example_meaning: There are many people here.

ch_gram_a1_12.title: Possessive Adjectives
ch_gram_a1_12.theory:
## Possessive Adjectives

| Person | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| yo | **mi** | **mis** |
| tú | **tu** | **tus** |
| él/ella/usted | **su** | **sus** |
| nosotros | **nuestro/a** | **nuestros/as** |
| vosotros | **vuestro/a** | **vuestros/as** |
| ellos/ustedes | **su** | **sus** |

### Usage
- **Mi** libro. → My book. / **Mis** libros. → My books.
- **Tu** casa. → Your house. / **Tus** amigos. → Your friends.
- **Su** gato. → His/Her/Your(formal)/Their cat.

### Important Notes
- Possessives agree with the **thing possessed**, not the owner:
  - **Su** casa (his/her house) — not *sua* casa
- **Nuestro/vuestro** are the only ones with gender forms:
  - **Nuestro** coche (our car) / **Nuestra** casa (our house)
- **Su/sus** can be ambiguous — use "de él/de ella" to clarify:
  - **Su** libro = his/her book → El libro **de ella** = her book
key_points: mi/tu/su don't change for gender — only for number (mis/tus/sus)
nuestro/vuestro change for both gender AND number
su/sus can mean his/her/your(formal)/their
Possessives agree with the thing possessed, not the owner

vocab_list.example: Mi familia es grande.
vocab_list.example_meaning: My family is big.

vocab_list.example: ¿Cuál es tu nombre?
vocab_list.example_meaning: What is your name?

vocab_list.example: Nuestro país es bonito.
vocab_list.example_meaning: Our country is beautiful.

vocab_list.example: Sus hijos son simpáticos.
vocab_list.example_meaning: His/Her/Their children are nice.

ch_gram_a1_13.title: Demonstrative Adjectives
ch_gram_a1_13.theory:
## Demonstrative Adjectives: This, That, That (over there)

Spanish has three levels of distance:

| Distance | Masculine | Feminine | Masc. Pl. | Fem. Pl. |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Near (this) | **este** | **esta** | **estos** | **estas** |
| Medium (that) | **ese** | **esa** | **esos** | **esas** |
| Far (that over there) | **aquel** | **aquella** | **aquellos** | **aquellas** |

### Examples
- **Este** libro es bueno. (This book is good.) — near speaker
- **Esa** casa es grande. (That house is big.) — near listener
- **Aquel** edificio es alto. (That building over there is tall.) — far from both

### Tip
- **este** → here (aquí)
- **ese** → there (ahí)
- **aquel** → over there (allí)
key_points: Three levels: este (near me), ese (near you), aquel (far from both)
Must agree in gender and number with the noun
este→aquí, ese→ahí, aquel→allí
English only has two (this/that); Spanish has three

vocab_list.example: Este coche es rojo.
vocab_list.example_meaning: This car is red.

vocab_list.example: Esa chica es mi amiga.
vocab_list.example_meaning: That girl is my friend.

vocab_list.example: Aquellos edificios son modernos.
vocab_list.example_meaning: Those buildings over there are modern.

vocab_list.example: Estas flores son bonitas.
vocab_list.example_meaning: These flowers are pretty.

ch_gram_a1_14.title: Prepositions
ch_gram_a1_14.theory:
## Common Prepositions

### Basic Prepositions
| Preposition | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **en** | in, on, at | Vivo **en** Madrid. |
| **de** | of, from | Soy **de** España. |
| **a** | to, at | Voy **a** la escuela. |
| **con** | with | Café **con** leche. |
| **sin** | without | Café **sin** azúcar. |
| **para** | for, in order to | Es **para** ti. |
| **por** | for, by, through | Gracias **por** todo. |

### Preposition + Article Contractions
- **a + el = al**: Voy **al** cine.
- **de + el = del**: Vengo **del** trabajo.

### Key Uses of "a"
- Direction: Voy **a** Madrid.
- Personal "a" (before people): Veo **a** mi madre. (I see my mother.)
- Time: **A** las tres. (At three o'clock.)

### En vs A
- **en** = inside/at a place: Estoy **en** el banco.
- **a** = direction/destination: Voy **a** el banco → Voy **al** banco.
key_points: Contractions: a + el = al, de + el = del
Personal 'a' before people: Veo a mi madre
en = location (at/in), a = direction (to)
de = origin/possession: Soy de España, El libro de María

vocab_list.example: El libro está en la mesa.
vocab_list.example_meaning: The book is on the table.

vocab_list.example: Soy de Colombia.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I am from Colombia.

vocab_list.example: Voy con mis amigos.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I go with my friends.

vocab_list.example: Este regalo es para ti.
vocab_list.example_meaning: This gift is for you.

ch_gram_a1_15.title: Question Words
ch_gram_a1_15.theory:
## Question Words (Interrogatives)

All Spanish question words have a written accent.

| Word | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **¿Qué?** | What? | ¿**Qué** es esto? |
| **¿Quién/Quiénes?** | Who? | ¿**Quién** es ella? |
| **¿Dónde?** | Where? | ¿**Dónde** vives? |
| **¿Cuándo?** | When? | ¿**Cuándo** es la fiesta? |
| **¿Cómo?** | How? | ¿**Cómo** estás? |
| **¿Cuánto/a/os/as?** | How much/many? | ¿**Cuántos** años tienes? |
| **¿Por qué?** | Why? | ¿**Por qué** estudias español? |
| **¿Cuál/Cuáles?** | Which? | ¿**Cuál** es tu nombre? |

### Punctuation
Spanish uses inverted question marks at the beginning: **¿...?**

### Qué vs Cuál
- **¿Qué es?** = What is it? (definition)
- **¿Cuál es?** = Which one is it? (choice/selection)
- **¿Cuál es tu nombre?** = What is your name? (choosing among names)
key_points: All question words have written accents: qué, quién, dónde, etc.
Spanish uses inverted question mark at start: ¿...?
Cuánto agrees in gender/number: cuánto/cuánta/cuántos/cuántas
Qué (definition) vs Cuál (selection)

vocab_list.example: ¿Qué hora es?

ch_gram_a1_16.title: Negation
ch_gram_a1_16.theory:
## Forming Negative Sentences

### Basic Rule
Place **no** directly before the verb:
- Hablo español. → **No** hablo español. (I don't speak Spanish.)
- Es fácil. → **No** es fácil. (It is not easy.)

### Negative Words
| Affirmative | Negative |
|---|---|
| algo (something) | **nada** (nothing) |
| alguien (someone) | **nadie** (nobody) |
| siempre (always) | **nunca** (never) |
| también (also) | **tampoco** (neither) |

### Double Negatives (Allowed in Spanish!)
Unlike English, Spanish allows double negatives:
- **No** tengo **nada**. = I don't have anything. (lit. I don't have nothing.)
- **No** viene **nadie**. = Nobody is coming.
- **No** como **nunca** carne. = I never eat meat.

### Negative Before Verb (no double negative needed)
- **Nada** es perfecto. = Nothing is perfect.
- **Nunca** llueve aquí. = It never rains here.
key_points: Place 'no' before the verb to negate
Double negatives are correct in Spanish: No tengo nada
nada (nothing), nadie (nobody), nunca (never), tampoco (neither)
Negative word before verb = no 'no' needed: Nunca llueve

vocab_list.example_meaning: I don't speak French.

ch_gram_a1_17.title: Verb Gustar (Basics)
ch_gram_a1_17.theory:
## How Gustar Works

**Gustar** literally means "to please" — it works backwards compared to English "to like".

### Structure
**(Indirect Object) + gusta/gustan + subject**

| Person | Structure | Example |
|---|---|---|
| I like | **Me gusta(n)** | Me gusta el café. |
| You like | **Te gusta(n)** | Te gustan los gatos. |
| He/She likes | **Le gusta(n)** | Le gusta bailar. |
| We like | **Nos gusta(n)** | Nos gusta la música. |
| You all like | **Os gusta(n)** | Os gustan las películas. |
| They like | **Les gusta(n)** | Les gusta viajar. |

### Gusta vs Gustan
- **Gusta** + singular noun / infinitive: Me **gusta** el chocolate. / Me **gusta** leer.
- **Gustan** + plural noun: Me **gustan** los perros.

### Emphasis/Clarification
Add **a mí, a ti, a él/ella...** for emphasis:
- **A mí** me gusta, pero **a él** no le gusta.
key_points: Gustar = 'to please' — subject and object are reversed vs English
Gusta + singular/infinitive, gustan + plural
Indirect object pronouns: me, te, le, nos, os, les
Add 'a mí/a ti/a él' for emphasis or clarification

vocab_list.example: Me gusta la música.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I like music.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I love chocolate.

ch_gram_a1_18.title: Verb Tener + Expressions
ch_gram_a1_18.theory:
## Tener — Present Tense Conjugation

| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **tengo** |
| tú | **tienes** |
| él/ella/usted | **tiene** |
| nosotros/as | **tenemos** |
| vosotros/as | **tenéis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **tienen** |

### Basic Meaning: to have
- **Tengo** un perro. (I have a dog.)
- Ella **tiene** dos hermanos. (She has two siblings.)

### Tener + Noun Expressions (English uses 'to be')
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| tener hambre | to be hungry |
| tener sed | to be thirsty |
| tener sueño | to be sleepy |
| tener frío | to be cold |
| tener calor | to be hot |
| tener miedo | to be afraid |
| tener razón | to be right |
| tener prisa | to be in a hurry |
| tener ... años | to be ... years old |

**Tengo** 20 **años**. = I am 20 years old. (lit. I have 20 years.)
key_points: Tener is irregular: tengo, tienes, tiene, tenemos, tenéis, tienen
Tener + noun = English 'to be + adjective': tener hambre = to be hungry
Age uses tener: Tengo 25 años (I am 25 years old)
Many idiomatic expressions: tener razón, tener prisa, tener miedo

vocab_list.example_meaning: I have a brother.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I am very hungry.

ch_gram_a1_19.title: Verb Ir + a + Place
ch_gram_a1_19.theory:
## Ir — Present Tense Conjugation

| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **voy** |
| tú | **vas** |
| él/ella/usted | **va** |
| nosotros/as | **vamos** |
| vosotros/as | **vais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **van** |

### Ir + a + Place
- **Voy a** la escuela. (I go to school.)
- **Vamos al** cine. (We go to the cinema.) — a + el = al
- ¿Adónde **vas**? (Where are you going?)

### Ir + a + Infinitive (Near Future)
**Ir a + infinitive** expresses plans or intentions:
- **Voy a estudiar**. (I am going to study.)
- **Vamos a comer**. (We are going to eat.)
- ¿**Vas a viajar** este verano? (Are you going to travel this summer?)

### ¡Vamos!
- **¡Vamos!** = Let's go!
- **Vamos a + infinitive** = Let's ... : **Vamos a bailar.** (Let's dance.)
key_points: Ir is highly irregular: voy, vas, va, vamos, vais, van
Ir a + place = to go to: Voy a la escuela
Ir a + infinitive = near future: Voy a estudiar (I'm going to study)
Remember: a + el = al → Voy al parque

vocab_list.example_meaning: I go to the supermarket.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Shall we go to the cinema?

ch_gram_a1_20.title: Numbers (1-100)
ch_gram_a1_20.theory:
## Numbers 1-30

| Number | Spanish | Number | Spanish |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | **uno** | 11 | **once** |
| 2 | **dos** | 12 | **doce** |
| 3 | **tres** | 13 | **trece** |
| 4 | **cuatro** | 14 | **catorce** |
| 5 | **cinco** | 15 | **quince** |
| 6 | **seis** | 16 | **dieciséis** |
| 7 | **siete** | 17 | **diecisiete** |
| 8 | **ocho** | 18 | **dieciocho** |
| 9 | **nueve** | 19 | **diecinueve** |
| 10 | **diez** | 20 | **veinte** |

21-29: **veinti-** + unit → **veintiuno**, **veintidós**, **veintitrés**...

## Numbers 30-100
| Number | Spanish |
|---|---|
| 30 | **treinta** |
| 40 | **cuarenta** |
| 50 | **cincuenta** |
| 60 | **sesenta** |
| 70 | **setenta** |
| 80 | **ochenta** |
| 90 | **noventa** |
| 100 | **cien** |

31-99: tens + **y** + units → **treinta y uno**, **cuarenta y cinco**, **noventa y nueve**

### Note
- **uno** → **un** before masculine nouns: **veintiún** libros
- **uno** → **una** before feminine nouns: **veintiuna** casas
key_points: 1-15 have unique forms; 16-19 are dieci- compounds
21-29 are veinti- compounds (one word)
31-99 use tens + y + units (two words): treinta y dos
uno → un (masc.) / una (fem.) before nouns

ch_vocab_a1_01.title: Greetings & Basic Expressions
ch_vocab_a1_01.theory:
## Basic Greetings

Let's learn the most common Spanish greetings.

### Time-based Greetings
- **Buenos días** - Good morning (until ~1pm)
- **Buenas tardes** - Good afternoon (until ~8pm)
- **Buenas noches** - Good evening / Good night

### Meeting and Parting
- **¡Hola!** - Hi! (any time of day)
- **¿Qué tal?** / **¿Cómo estás?** - How are you? (informal)
- **¿Cómo está usted?** - How are you? (formal)
- **¡Adiós!** - Goodbye!
- **¡Hasta luego!** - See you later!
- **¡Hasta mañana!** - See you tomorrow!

### Thanks and Apologies
- **Gracias** / **Muchas gracias** - Thank you / Thank you very much
- **De nada** - You're welcome
- **Perdón** / **Disculpe** - Sorry / Excuse me

### Basic Phrases
- **Sí** / **No** - Yes / No
- **Por favor** - Please
- **Lo siento** - I'm sorry
key_points: ¡Hola! can be used at any time of day
Time-based greetings: días (morning), tardes (afternoon), noches (evening)
¿Cómo estás? (informal) vs ¿Cómo está? (formal)
Perdón (minor) vs Lo siento (apology)

vocab_list.example_meaning: Hi! How are you?

ch_vocab_a1_03.title: Numbers & Time
ch_vocab_a1_03.theory:
## Telling Time in Spanish

### Asking the Time
- **¿Qué hora es?** - What time is it?

### Answering
- **Es la una.** - It is 1:00. (singular for 1)
- **Son las dos.** - It is 2:00. (plural for 2-12)
- **Son las tres y media.** - It is 3:30.
- **Son las cuatro y cuarto.** - It is 4:15.
- **Son las cinco menos cuarto.** - It is 4:45.

### Time Vocabulary
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **y media** | half past |
| **y cuarto** | quarter past |
| **menos cuarto** | quarter to |
| **en punto** | o'clock (sharp) |
| **de la mañana** | in the morning (AM) |
| **de la tarde** | in the afternoon (PM) |
| **de la noche** | at night (PM) |

### Examples
- Son las ocho **de la mañana**. (It's 8 AM.)
- Son las diez **y diez** de la noche. (It's 10:10 PM.)
key_points: Es la una (singular) vs Son las dos/tres... (plural)
y media (30), y cuarto (15), menos cuarto (45)
de la mañana/tarde/noche for AM/PM
¿A qué hora? = At what time? — A las tres. = At 3:00.

**Note**: Days are NOT capitalized in Spanish. Use **el/los** with days: Trabajo **el lunes**. / No trabajo **los sábados**.

## Months

**enero, febrero, marzo, abril, mayo, junio, julio, agosto, septiembre, octubre, noviembre, diciembre**

Months are also NOT capitalized: Mi cumpleaños es en **marzo**.

## Seasons

key_points: Days and months are NOT capitalized in Spanish
Use el/los with days: el lunes (on Monday), los viernes (on Fridays)
Months use 'en': en marzo, en diciembre
Week starts on lunes (Monday) in Spanish-speaking countries

ch_vocab_a1_05.title: Colors
ch_vocab_a1_05.theory:
## Colors in Spanish

### Colors That Change for Gender
| Masculine | Feminine | English |
|---|---|---|
| **rojo** | **roja** | red |
| **blanco** | **blanca** | white |
| **negro** | **negra** | black |
| **amarillo** | **amarilla** | yellow |

### Colors That Do NOT Change for Gender
These only change for number (add -s/-es for plural):
- **azul** → azules (blue)
- **verde** → verdes (green)
- **gris** → grises (gray)
- **marrón** → marrones (brown)
- **naranja** → naranjas (orange)
- **rosa** → rosas (pink)

### Usage
Colors go **after** the noun:
- Un coche **rojo**. (A red car.)
- Una casa **blanca**. (A white house.)
- Ojos **azules**. (Blue eyes.)

### Asking About Color
- ¿De qué color es? (What color is it?)
- Es **rojo**. / Es **azul**.
key_points: Colors ending in -o change gender: rojo/roja, blanco/blanca
Colors ending in -e or consonant don't change gender: verde, azul, gris
Colors go AFTER the noun: un coche rojo
All colors change for number: rojo→rojos, azul→azules

vocab_list.example_meaning: The car is red.

| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **Llueve.** (llover) | It rains. / It's raining. |

- **Hay niebla.** - It's foggy.

ch_gram_a2_01.title: Stem-Changing Verbs (e→ie)
ch_gram_a2_01.theory:
## Stem-Changing Verbs: e→ie

Some Spanish verbs change the **e** in their stem to **ie** when conjugated in the present tense. This is one of the most common stem-change patterns and affects **-ar**, **-er**, and **-ir** verbs alike.

### The Boot/Shoe Pattern

The stem change happens in **all forms EXCEPT nosotros and vosotros**. If you draw a line around the changed forms in a conjugation table, it looks like a boot or shoe — hence the name "boot verbs."

### Conjugation: pensar (to think)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | p**ie**nso |
| tú | p**ie**nsas |
| él/ella/usted | p**ie**nsa |
| nosotros/as | p**e**nsamos |
| vosotros/as | p**e**nsáis |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | p**ie**nsan |

### More Examples
| Verb | Meaning | yo form |
|---|---|---|
| **querer** | to want/love | qu**ie**ro |
| **entender** | to understand | ent**ie**ndo |
| **preferir** | to prefer | pref**ie**ro |
| **empezar** | to begin | emp**ie**zo |
| **cerrar** | to close | c**ie**rro |
| **perder** | to lose | p**ie**rdo |
| **sentir** | to feel | s**ie**nto |

### Important Rules
- The **stem change only affects the stressed syllable**. In nosotros/vosotros, the stress falls on the ending, so the stem stays regular.
- The **verb endings remain completely regular** — only the stem vowel changes.
- You must **memorize which verbs are stem-changing**; there is no rule to predict them from the infinitive alone.

### Example Sentences
- **Quiero** un café. (I want a coffee.)
- ¿**Entiendes** la pregunta? (Do you understand the question?)
- Ella **prefiere** el té. (She prefers tea.)
- Nosotros **pensamos** mucho. (We think a lot.) — no change!
key_points: The e in the stem changes to ie in all forms EXCEPT nosotros and vosotros
This is called the 'boot pattern' because the changed forms form a boot shape
Works with -ar, -er, and -ir verbs: pensar, querer, preferir
Key verbs: pensar, querer, entender, preferir, empezar, cerrar, perder, sentir

vocab_list.example: Pienso que es una buena idea.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I think it is a good idea.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I want to learn Spanish.

ch_gram_a2_02.title: Stem-Changing Verbs (o→ue)
ch_gram_a2_02.theory:
## Stem-Changing Verbs: o→ue

The second major stem-change pattern turns **o** into **ue** in the present tense. Like e→ie verbs, this follows the **boot pattern** — the change occurs in all persons except nosotros and vosotros.

### Conjugation: poder (to be able to / can)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | p**ue**do |
| tú | p**ue**des |
| él/ella/usted | p**ue**de |
| nosotros/as | p**o**demos |
| vosotros/as | p**o**déis |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | p**ue**den |

### Common o→ue Verbs
| Verb | Meaning | yo form |
|---|---|---|
| **dormir** | to sleep | d**ue**rmo |
| **volver** | to return | v**ue**lvo |
| **encontrar** | to find | enc**ue**ntro |
| **contar** | to count/tell | c**ue**nto |
| **recordar** | to remember | rec**ue**rdo |
| **morir** | to die | m**ue**ro |
| **almorzar** | to have lunch | alm**ue**rzo |
| **costar** | to cost | c**ue**sta |

### Special Case: jugar (u→ue)
**Jugar** (to play) is the only verb with a **u→ue** change:
- j**ue**go, j**ue**gas, j**ue**ga, jugamos, jugáis, j**ue**gan

### Key Points
- The boot pattern is the same: change in yo, tú, él/ella, ellos/ellas — NOT in nosotros/vosotros.
- **Costar** is usually used in 3rd person: ¿Cuánto **cuesta**? (How much does it cost?) / ¿Cuánto **cuestan**? (How much do they cost?)
- **Volver a + infinitive** = to do something again: **Vuelvo a** leer el libro. (I read the book again.)

### Example Sentences
- No **puedo** ir a la fiesta. (I can't go to the party.)
- ¿A qué hora **vuelves** a casa? (What time do you return home?)
- Los niños **duermen** ocho horas. (The children sleep eight hours.)
- **Almorzamos** a las dos. (We have lunch at two.) — no change!
key_points: The o in the stem changes to ue in all forms EXCEPT nosotros and vosotros
Same boot pattern as e→ie verbs
Special: jugar is the only u→ue verb (juego, juegas, juega...)
Key verbs: poder, dormir, volver, encontrar, contar, recordar, almorzar, costar

vocab_list.example_meaning: Can you help me?

ch_gram_a2_03.title: Stem-Changing Verbs (e→i)
ch_gram_a2_03.theory:
## Stem-Changing Verbs: e→i

The third stem-change pattern turns **e** into **i**. Unlike e→ie and o→ue, this pattern **only applies to -ir verbs**.

### Conjugation: pedir (to ask for / to order)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | p**i**do |
| tú | p**i**des |
| él/ella/usted | p**i**de |
| nosotros/as | p**e**dimos |
| vosotros/as | p**e**dís |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | p**i**den |

### Common e→i Verbs
| Verb | Meaning | yo form |
|---|---|---|
| **servir** | to serve | s**i**rvo |
| **repetir** | to repeat | rep**i**to |
| **seguir** | to follow/continue | s**i**go |
| **vestirse** | to get dressed | me v**i**sto |
| **reír** | to laugh | r**í**o |
| **sonreír** | to smile | sonr**í**o |
| **elegir** | to choose | el**i**jo |
| **medir** | to measure | m**i**do |

### Important Notes
- **Only -ir verbs** have the e→i change. There are no -ar or -er verbs with this pattern.
- The **boot pattern** is the same: nosotros and vosotros keep the regular stem.
- **Seguir** has a spelling change too: the **u** is dropped before **o**: sigo (not *siguo*).
- **Elegir** also has a spelling change: elijo (g→j before o).
- **Reír** and **sonreír** have accent marks: río, ríes, ríe, reímos, reís, ríen.

### Example Sentences
- **Pido** una pizza. (I order a pizza.)
- El camarero **sirve** la comida. (The waiter serves the food.)
- ¿Por qué **repites** la pregunta? (Why do you repeat the question?)
- **Seguimos** caminando. (We keep walking.) — no stem change!
key_points: The e→i change ONLY occurs with -ir verbs, never with -ar or -er
Same boot pattern: change in all forms except nosotros/vosotros
seguir drops the u before o: sigo (not siguo)
Key verbs: pedir, servir, repetir, seguir, vestirse, reír, elegir

vocab_list.example_meaning: I order a coffee in the restaurant.

ch_gram_a2_04.title: Reflexive Verbs
ch_gram_a2_04.theory:
## Reflexive Verbs (Verbos Reflexivos)

Reflexive verbs indicate that the subject performs and receives the action — the subject does something **to themselves**. They are identified by the pronoun **-se** attached to the infinitive: lavarse, levantarse, vestirse.

### Reflexive Pronouns
| Person | Pronoun |
|---|---|
| yo | **me** |
| tú | **te** |
| él/ella/usted | **se** |
| nosotros/as | **nos** |
| vosotros/as | **os** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **se** |

### Conjugation: levantarse (to get up)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **me** levanto |
| tú | **te** levantas |
| él/ella/usted | **se** levanta |
| nosotros/as | **nos** levantamos |
| vosotros/as | **os** levantáis |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **se** levantan |

### Common Reflexive Verbs (Daily Routine)
| Verb | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **levantarse** | to get up |
| **ducharse** | to shower |
| **lavarse** | to wash (oneself) |
| **vestirse** | to get dressed |
| **peinarse** | to comb one's hair |
| **acostarse** | to go to bed |
| **dormirse** | to fall asleep |
| **sentarse** | to sit down |

### Pronoun Placement Rules
1. **Before a conjugated verb**: Me levanto a las siete.
2. **Attached to an infinitive**: Voy a levantarme temprano. OR Me voy a levantar temprano.
3. **Attached to a gerund**: Estoy duchándome. OR Me estoy duchando.

### Reflexive vs Non-Reflexive Meaning Changes
| Non-Reflexive | Reflexive |
|---|---|
| **ir** (to go) | **irse** (to leave/go away) |
| **dormir** (to sleep) | **dormirse** (to fall asleep) |
| **llamar** (to call) | **llamarse** (to be called/named) |
| **poner** (to put) | **ponerse** (to put on / to become) |
key_points: Reflexive pronouns: me, te, se, nos, os, se — placed before the conjugated verb
The pronoun can attach to infinitives and gerunds: levantarme, duchándome
Many daily routine verbs are reflexive: levantarse, ducharse, vestirse, acostarse
Some verbs change meaning when reflexive: ir (to go) vs irse (to leave)

vocab_list.example_meaning: I get up at seven in the morning.

ch_gram_a2_05.title: Direct Object Pronouns
ch_gram_a2_05.theory:
## Direct Object Pronouns (DOPs)

A direct object receives the action of the verb directly. Direct object pronouns **replace** the direct object noun to avoid repetition.

### The Pronouns
| Person | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| 1st | **me** (me) | **nos** (us) |
| 2nd informal | **te** (you) | **os** (you all) |
| 3rd masculine | **lo** (him/it) | **los** (them) |
| 3rd feminine | **la** (her/it) | **las** (them) |
| 2nd formal | **lo/la** (you) | **los/las** (you all) |

### How It Works
Identify the direct object (what/whom receives the action) and replace it:
- Compro **el libro**. → **Lo** compro. (I buy it.)
- ¿Ves **a María**? → ¿**La** ves? (Do you see her?)
- Comemos **las manzanas**. → **Las** comemos. (We eat them.)
- Leo **los periódicos**. → **Los** leo. (I read them.)

### Position Rules
1. **Before a conjugated verb**: **Lo** compro. (I buy it.)
2. **Attached to an infinitive**: Voy a comprar**lo**. OR **Lo** voy a comprar.
3. **Attached to a gerund**: Estoy comprando**lo**. OR **Lo** estoy comprando.
4. **Attached to affirmative commands**: ¡Cómpralo! (Buy it!)
5. **Before negative commands**: ¡No **lo** compres! (Don't buy it!)

### Important Notes
- **Lo** can mean "him," "it" (masculine), or "you" (formal masculine).
- **La** can mean "her," "it" (feminine), or "you" (formal feminine).
- When a pronoun is attached to a verb, an **accent mark** may be needed to maintain stress: comprándolo, cómpralo.
key_points: DOPs replace direct objects: lo (him/it), la (her/it), los (them m.), las (them f.)
Position: before conjugated verb OR attached to infinitive/gerund/affirmative command
Lo/la also serve as formal 'you': ¿Lo ayudo? (Can I help you, sir?)
Accent marks are added when attaching to gerunds and commands: comprándolo, cómpralo

vocab_list.example: ¿El libro? Lo compro mañana.
vocab_list.example_meaning: The book? I'll buy it tomorrow.

vocab_list.example: ¿A María? La veo todos los días.
vocab_list.example_meaning: María? I see her every day.

vocab_list.example: Te llamo esta noche.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I'll call you tonight.

vocab_list.example: ¿Me puedes ayudar?
vocab_list.example_meaning: Can you help me?

ch_gram_a2_06.title: Indirect Object Pronouns
ch_gram_a2_06.theory:
## Indirect Object Pronouns (IOPs)

An indirect object indicates **to whom** or **for whom** an action is done. Indirect object pronouns replace the indirect object noun.

### The Pronouns
| Person | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| 1st | **me** (to me) | **nos** (to us) |
| 2nd informal | **te** (to you) | **os** (to you all) |
| 3rd | **le** (to him/her/you formal) | **les** (to them/you all formal) |

### How It Works
- Doy el libro **a María**. → **Le** doy el libro. (I give her the book.)
- Escribo una carta **a mis padres**. → **Les** escribo una carta. (I write them a letter.)
- El profesor explica la lección **a nosotros**. → El profesor **nos** explica la lección.

### Clarifying le/les
Since **le** can mean "to him," "to her," or "to you (formal)," add **a + pronoun** for clarity:
- **Le** doy el libro **a él**. (I give the book to him.)
- **Le** doy el libro **a ella**. (I give the book to her.)
- **Le** doy el libro **a usted**. (I give the book to you.)

### Position Rules
Same as DOPs:
1. **Before conjugated verb**: **Le** doy el libro.
2. **Attached to infinitive**: Voy a dar**le** el libro. OR **Le** voy a dar el libro.
3. **Attached to gerund**: Estoy dándo**le** el libro. OR **Le** estoy dando el libro.

### Gustar-Type Verbs Use IOPs
Verbs like gustar, encantar, interesar, and molestar always use indirect object pronouns:
- **Me** gusta el café. (Coffee pleases **me** = I like coffee.)
- **Les** encanta la música. (Music delights **them** = They love music.)
- **Te** interesa la historia. (History interests **you** = You're interested in history.)

### Common Verbs That Take Indirect Objects
dar (to give), decir (to tell), escribir (to write), enviar (to send), explicar (to explain), preguntar (to ask), regalar (to give as gift).
key_points: IOPs: me, te, le, nos, os, les — indicate 'to whom' or 'for whom'
le/les are ambiguous — clarify with 'a él/ella/usted/ellos/ellas/ustedes'
Same position rules as DOPs: before verb or attached to infinitive/gerund
Gustar-type verbs always use IOPs: Me gusta, Te interesa, Le encanta

ch_gram_a2_07.title: Present Progressive
ch_gram_a2_07.theory:
## Present Progressive (Estar + Gerund)

The present progressive describes an action that is happening **right now**, at this very moment.

### Formation
**estar (conjugated) + gerund (-ando / -iendo)**

### Forming the Gerund
| Verb Type | Rule | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **-ar** verbs | stem + **-ando** | hablar → habl**ando** |
| **-er** verbs | stem + **-iendo** | comer → com**iendo** |
| **-ir** verbs | stem + **-iendo** | vivir → viv**iendo** |

### Irregular Gerunds
| Verb | Gerund | Rule |
|---|---|---|
| **leer** | le**yendo** | vowel + -iendo → -yendo |
| **oír** | o**yendo** | vowel + -iendo → -yendo |
| **dormir** | d**u**rm**iendo** | o→u stem change |
| **pedir** | p**i**d**iendo** | e→i stem change |
| **decir** | d**i**c**iendo** | e→i stem change |
| **ir** | **yendo** | special form |
| **poder** | p**u**d**iendo** | o→u stem change |

### Conjugation Example: estar comiendo
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **estoy** comiendo |
| tú | **estás** comiendo |
| él/ella/usted | **está** comiendo |
| nosotros/as | **estamos** comiendo |
| vosotros/as | **estáis** comiendo |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **están** comiendo |

### Usage: Spanish vs English
- Spanish present progressive is used **only for actions happening right now**.
- Do NOT use it for future plans (unlike English):
  - "I'm eating lunch" (now) = **Estoy almorzando.** ✓
  - "I'm traveling tomorrow" = **Viajo mañana.** ✓ (simple present, NOT *Estoy viajando mañana*)

### Example Sentences
- ¿Qué **estás haciendo**? (What are you doing?)
- **Estoy estudiando** para el examen. (I am studying for the exam.)
- Los niños **están jugando** en el parque. (The children are playing in the park.)
key_points: Formation: estar (conjugated) + gerund (-ando for -ar, -iendo for -er/-ir)
Irregular gerunds: leyendo, durmiendo, pidiendo, diciendo, yendo
Only for actions happening RIGHT NOW — not for future plans like in English
Pronouns can go before estar or attached to gerund: Lo estoy leyendo / Estoy leyéndolo

vocab_list.example: Estoy hablando por teléfono.
vocab_list.example_meaning: I am speaking on the phone.

vocab_list.example_meaning: We are eating at a restaurant.

ch_gram_a2_08.title: Near Future (ir a + infinitive)
ch_gram_a2_08.theory:
## Near Future: ir a + infinitive

The most common way to talk about the future in everyday Spanish is using **ir (conjugated) + a + infinitive**. This is equivalent to English "going to + verb."

### Formation
**ir (conjugated) + a + infinitive**

### Conjugation of ir (Present)
| Person | ir |
|---|---|
| yo | **voy** |
| tú | **vas** |
| él/ella/usted | **va** |
| nosotros/as | **vamos** |
| vosotros/as | **vais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **van** |

### Examples
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **Voy a estudiar** esta noche. | I'm going to study tonight. |
| ¿**Vas a viajar** este verano? | Are you going to travel this summer? |
| Ella **va a cocinar** la cena. | She is going to cook dinner. |
| **Vamos a ver** una película. | We are going to watch a movie. |
| Ellos **van a comprar** una casa. | They are going to buy a house. |

### When to Use It
- **Plans and intentions**: Voy a estudiar medicina. (I'm going to study medicine.)
- **Predictions**: Va a llover mañana. (It's going to rain tomorrow.)
- **Immediate future**: Voy a salir ahora. (I'm going to leave now.)

### Common Time Expressions
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **mañana** | tomorrow |
| **esta noche** | tonight |
| **este fin de semana** | this weekend |
| **la semana que viene** | next week |
| **el próximo mes** | next month |
| **el año que viene** | next year |

### Negative Form
Place **no** before the conjugated form of ir:
- **No voy a** trabajar mañana. (I'm not going to work tomorrow.)
- **No van a** venir. (They are not going to come.)

### ir a + infinitive vs Simple Future
In spoken Spanish, **ir a + infinitive** is much more common than the simple future tense (hablaré, comeré). The simple future is more formal or literary.
key_points: Formation: conjugated ir + a + infinitive (Voy a estudiar)
More common in speech than the simple future tense (estudiaré)
Used for plans, intentions, predictions, and immediate future
Negative: No + ir conjugated + a + infinitive: No voy a ir

vocab_list.example: Vamos a viajar a España este verano.
vocab_list.example_meaning: We are going to travel to Spain this summer.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I am going to study tomorrow.

ch_gram_a2_09.title: Preterite Regular Verbs
ch_gram_a2_09.theory:
## Preterite Tense: Regular Verbs

The preterite (pretérito indefinido) is used to talk about **completed actions in the past** — events with a clear beginning and/or end.

### -ar Verbs: hablar (to speak)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | habl**é** |
| tú | habl**aste** |
| él/ella/usted | habl**ó** |
| nosotros/as | habl**amos** |
| vosotros/as | habl**asteis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | habl**aron** |

### -er Verbs: comer (to eat)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | com**í** |
| tú | com**iste** |
| él/ella/usted | com**ió** |
| nosotros/as | com**imos** |
| vosotros/as | com**isteis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | com**ieron** |

### -ir Verbs: vivir (to live)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | viv**í** |
| tú | viv**iste** |
| él/ella/usted | viv**ió** |
| nosotros/as | viv**imos** |
| vosotros/as | viv**isteis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | viv**ieron** |

**Note**: -er and -ir verbs share the **exact same** preterite endings!

### Time Markers for Preterite
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **ayer** | yesterday |
| **anoche** | last night |
| **la semana pasada** | last week |
| **el mes pasado** | last month |
| **el año pasado** | last year |
| **hace dos días** | two days ago |

### When to Use the Preterite
- **Single completed action**: Ayer **compré** un libro. (Yesterday I bought a book.)
- **Action with clear time frame**: **Viví** en Madrid dos años. (I lived in Madrid for two years.)
- **Series of completed actions**: Me **levanté**, **desayuné** y **salí**. (I got up, had breakfast, and left.)
key_points: -ar endings: -é, -aste, -ó, -amos, -asteis, -aron
-er/-ir endings: -í, -iste, -ió, -imos, -isteis, -ieron (identical!)
Used for completed past actions with a clear beginning or end
Time markers: ayer, anoche, la semana pasada, hace + time

vocab_list.example_meaning: Yesterday I studied for three hours.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Last night we ate at a restaurant.

ch_gram_a2_10.title: Preterite Irregular Verbs
ch_gram_a2_10.theory:
## Preterite Tense: Irregular Verbs

Many of the most common Spanish verbs are irregular in the preterite. These must be memorized.

### ir / ser (Same Forms!)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **fui** |
| tú | **fuiste** |
| él/ella/usted | **fue** |
| nosotros/as | **fuimos** |
| vosotros/as | **fuisteis** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **fueron** |

Context tells you whether it means "went" or "was":
- **Fui** al cine. (I went to the cinema.) — ir
- **Fue** una fiesta genial. (It was a great party.) — ser

### hacer (to do/make)
yo **hice**, tú **hiciste**, él **hizo**, nosotros **hicimos**, vosotros **hicisteis**, ellos **hicieron**

Note: él/ella form is **hizo** (c→z to preserve the sound).

### Other Key Irregulars (Special Stems)
| Verb | Stem | yo | tú | él | nosotros | ellos |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **tener** | tuv- | tuve | tuviste | tuvo | tuvimos | tuvieron |
| **estar** | estuv- | estuve | estuviste | estuvo | estuvimos | estuvieron |
| **poder** | pud- | pude | pudiste | pudo | pudimos | pudieron |
| **poner** | pus- | puse | pusiste | puso | pusimos | pusieron |
| **saber** | sup- | supe | supiste | supo | supimos | supieron |
| **venir** | vin- | vine | viniste | vino | vinimos | vinieron |
| **decir** | dij- | dije | dijiste | dijo | dijimos | dijeron |
| **traer** | traj- | traje | trajiste | trajo | trajimos | trajeron |

### Special Endings for Irregular Stems
These irregular verbs use special endings (no accents on yo/él):
**-e, -iste, -o, -imos, -isteis, -ieron** (or **-eron** after j: dijeron, trajeron)

### dar (to give)
yo **di**, tú **diste**, él **dio**, nosotros **dimos**, vosotros **disteis**, ellos **dieron**
(Uses -er/-ir endings but without accents.)
key_points: ir and ser share the same preterite forms: fui, fuiste, fue, fuimos, fueron
Irregular stems: tuv- (tener), estuv- (estar), pud- (poder), pus- (poner), vin- (venir)
Irregular stems use special unaccented endings: -e, -iste, -o, -imos, -ieron
hacer: hice, hiciste, hizo (c→z), hicimos, hicieron

vocab_list.example_meaning: What did you do yesterday?

ch_gram_a2_11.title: Imperfect Regular Verbs
ch_gram_a2_11.theory:
## Imperfect Tense: Regular Verbs

The imperfect (pretérito imperfecto) describes **ongoing, habitual, or repeated actions in the past**. It sets the scene and describes what things were like.

### -ar Verbs: hablar (to speak)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | habl**aba** |
| tú | habl**abas** |
| él/ella/usted | habl**aba** |
| nosotros/as | habl**ábamos** |
| vosotros/as | habl**abais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | habl**aban** |

### -er Verbs: comer (to eat)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | com**ía** |
| tú | com**ías** |
| él/ella/usted | com**ía** |
| nosotros/as | com**íamos** |
| vosotros/as | com**íais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | com**ían** |

### -ir Verbs: vivir (to live)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | viv**ía** |
| tú | viv**ías** |
| él/ella/usted | viv**ía** |
| nosotros/as | viv**íamos** |
| vosotros/as | viv**íais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | viv**ían** |

**Note**: -er and -ir verbs share the **exact same** imperfect endings! And the yo and él/ella forms are **identical** in each conjugation.

### When to Use the Imperfect
1. **Habitual past actions**: De niño, **jugaba** en el parque. (As a child, I used to play in the park.)
2. **Descriptions in the past**: La casa **era** grande y **tenía** un jardín. (The house was big and had a garden.)
3. **Age in the past**: Cuando **tenía** diez años... (When I was ten years old...)
4. **Time in the past**: **Eran** las tres de la tarde. (It was three in the afternoon.)
5. **Weather in the past**: **Hacía** mucho calor. (It was very hot.)
6. **Ongoing background action**: Mientras **estudiaba**, sonó el teléfono. (While I was studying, the phone rang.)

### Time Markers for Imperfect
- **siempre** (always), **a menudo** (often), **todos los días** (every day)
- **de niño/joven** (as a child/young person), **antes** (before/in the past)
- **mientras** (while), **generalmente** (generally)
key_points: -ar endings: -aba, -abas, -aba, -ábamos, -abais, -aban
-er/-ir endings: -ía, -ías, -ía, -íamos, -íais, -ían (identical!)
Used for habitual actions, descriptions, age, time, and weather in the past
Time markers: siempre, todos los días, de niño, mientras, a menudo

vocab_list.example_meaning: I always used to have breakfast at eight.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Every day I used to walk to school.

ch_gram_a2_12.title: Imperfect Irregular Verbs
ch_gram_a2_12.theory:
## Imperfect Tense: Irregular Verbs

The great news about the imperfect tense is that there are **only three irregular verbs**! Every other verb in Spanish is completely regular in the imperfect.

### ser (to be)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **era** |
| tú | **eras** |
| él/ella/usted | **era** |
| nosotros/as | **éramos** |
| vosotros/as | **erais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **eran** |

### ir (to go)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **iba** |
| tú | **ibas** |
| él/ella/usted | **iba** |
| nosotros/as | **íbamos** |
| vosotros/as | **ibais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **iban** |

### ver (to see)
| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | **veía** |
| tú | **veías** |
| él/ella/usted | **veía** |
| nosotros/as | **veíamos** |
| vosotros/as | **veíais** |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | **veían** |

**Note**: ver is only irregular because it keeps the **e** from the infinitive (ve-ía instead of the expected v-ía). The endings themselves are regular -er/-ir imperfect endings.

### Examples in Context
- Cuando **era** niño, **iba** al parque todos los días. (When I was a child, I went to the park every day.)
- Mi abuela **era** muy simpática. (My grandmother was very nice.)
- **Íbamos** a la playa cada verano. (We used to go to the beach every summer.)
- De joven, **veía** muchas películas. (When I was young, I used to watch many movies.)

### Why So Few Irregulars?
The imperfect tense evolved very regularly in Spanish. Compare this to the preterite, which has dozens of irregular verbs! This makes the imperfect one of the easiest tenses to learn.

### All Other Verbs Are Regular!
- tener → ten**ía**, ten**ías**, ten**ía**...
- hacer → hac**ía**, hac**ías**, hac**ía**...
- decir → dec**ía**, dec**ías**, dec**ía**...
- poder → pod**ía**, pod**ías**, pod**ía**...
key_points: Only THREE irregular verbs in the imperfect: ser (era), ir (iba), ver (veía)
ser: era, eras, era, éramos, erais, eran
ir: iba, ibas, iba, íbamos, ibais, iban
Every other Spanish verb is completely regular in the imperfect tense

ch_gram_a2_13.title: Preterite vs Imperfect
ch_gram_a2_13.theory:
## Preterite vs Imperfect: When to Use Each

Both tenses refer to the past, but they describe different types of past actions. Choosing between them is one of the biggest challenges at the A2 level.

### Preterite = Completed Action
The preterite views an action as a **single, completed event** with a clear beginning or end.
- **Ayer comí** paella. (Yesterday I ate paella.) — one specific event
- **Viví** en Madrid dos años. (I lived in Madrid for two years.) — completed time frame
- **Se levantó, desayunó y salió.** (He got up, had breakfast, and left.) — sequence of completed events

### Imperfect = Ongoing / Habitual
The imperfect describes **background, ongoing states, or habitual actions** without focus on beginning or end.
- De niño, **comía** mucha fruta. (As a child, I used to eat a lot of fruit.) — habit
- **Llovía** y **hacía** frío. (It was raining and it was cold.) — background description
- **Tenía** veinte años. (I was twenty years old.) — ongoing state

### The Key Contrast
| Preterite | Imperfect |
|---|---|
| Completed action | Ongoing / habitual action |
| Single event | Repeated event |
| Main event (foreground) | Background / scene-setting |
| Beginning or end | No focus on beginning or end |

### Classic Pattern: Background + Interruption
**Imperfect** (background) + **Preterite** (interruption):
- **Llovía** cuando **salí** de casa. (It was raining when I left the house.)
- **Dormía** cuando **sonó** el teléfono. (I was sleeping when the phone rang.)
- **Caminábamos** por la calle cuando **vimos** a Pedro. (We were walking down the street when we saw Pedro.)

### Trigger Words
| Preterite | Imperfect |
|---|---|
| ayer (yesterday) | siempre (always) |
| anoche (last night) | todos los días (every day) |
| una vez (once) | a menudo (often) |
| de repente (suddenly) | mientras (while) |
| la semana pasada (last week) | de niño (as a child) |

### Meaning Changes
Some verbs change meaning depending on the tense:
- **Conocí** a María. (I met María.) vs **Conocía** a María. (I knew María.)
- **Supe** la verdad. (I found out the truth.) vs **Sabía** la verdad. (I knew the truth.)
- **Pude** hacerlo. (I managed to do it.) vs **Podía** hacerlo. (I was able to / could do it.)
key_points: Preterite = completed, single event; Imperfect = ongoing, habitual, description
Classic pattern: Imperfect (background) + Preterite (interruption): Llovía cuando salí
Some verbs change meaning: conocí (met) vs conocía (knew), supe (found out) vs sabía (knew)
Trigger words: ayer/anoche/una vez (preterite) vs siempre/todos los días/mientras (imperfect)

vocab_list.example: Mientras estudiaba, sonó el teléfono.
vocab_list.example_meaning: While I was studying, the phone rang.

vocab_list.example_meaning: Suddenly, it started to rain.

ch_gram_a2_14.title: Comparatives
ch_gram_a2_14.theory:
## Comparatives (Comparativos)

Comparatives are used to compare two things, people, or actions.

### Superiority: más ... que (more ... than)
- María es **más alta que** Pedro. (María is taller than Pedro.)
- Este libro es **más interesante que** ese. (This book is more interesting than that one.)
- Ella habla **más rápido que** yo. (She speaks faster than me.)

### Inferiority: menos ... que (less ... than)
- Pedro es **menos alto que** María. (Pedro is less tall than María.)
- El invierno es **menos caluroso que** el verano. (Winter is less hot than summer.)

### Equality: tan ... como / tanto ... como
**tan + adjective/adverb + como** (as ... as):
- Ella es **tan inteligente como** su hermano. (She is as intelligent as her brother.)
- Corro **tan rápido como** tú. (I run as fast as you.)

**tanto/a/os/as + noun + como** (as much/many ... as):
- Tengo **tantos libros como** tú. (I have as many books as you.)
- Bebe **tanta agua como** yo. (He drinks as much water as me.)

**tanto como** (as much as — with verbs):
- Estudio **tanto como** tú. (I study as much as you.)

### Irregular Comparatives
Some adjectives have special comparative forms:
| Adjective | Comparative | English |
|---|---|---|
| **bueno** (good) | **mejor** | better |
| **malo** (bad) | **peor** | worse |
| **grande** (big/old) | **mayor** | older/bigger |
| **pequeño** (small/young) | **menor** | younger/smaller |

- Este restaurante es **mejor que** ese. (This restaurant is better than that one.)
- Mi hermano es **mayor que** yo. (My brother is older than me.)

**Note**: Do NOT say *más bueno* or *más malo* for comparisons. Use mejor/peor. However, más grande (bigger in size) is acceptable.

### Comparing Quantities with Numbers
**más de / menos de** + number:
- Hay **más de** veinte estudiantes. (There are more than twenty students.)
- Cuesta **menos de** diez euros. (It costs less than ten euros.)
key_points: Superiority: más + adj/adv + que; Inferiority: menos + adj/adv + que
Equality: tan + adj + como (as...as), tanto/a/os/as + noun + como (as many...as)
Irregular: mejor (better), peor (worse), mayor (older), menor (younger)
Before numbers use de instead of que: más de diez (more than ten)

vocab_list.example: Madrid es más grande que Sevilla.

ch_gram_a2_15.title: Superlatives
ch_gram_a2_15.theory:
## Superlatives (Superlativos)

Superlatives express the highest or lowest degree of a quality: "the most," "the least," "the best," "the worst."

### Relative Superlative
**el/la/los/las + más/menos + adjective (+ de)**

- Es **la ciudad más grande de** España. (It is the biggest city in Spain.)
- Es **el estudiante más inteligente de** la clase. (He is the smartest student in the class.)
- Es **la película menos interesante del** año. (It is the least interesting movie of the year.)

**Note**: Use **de** (not *en*) after superlatives: la más grande **de** la clase (the biggest in the class).

### Irregular Superlatives
| Adjective | Superlative | English |
|---|---|---|
| bueno | **el/la mejor** | the best |
| malo | **el/la peor** | the worst |
| grande | **el/la mayor** | the oldest/biggest |
| pequeño | **el/la menor** | the youngest/smallest |

- Es **el mejor** restaurante de la ciudad. (It is the best restaurant in the city.)
- Es **la peor** película que he visto. (It is the worst movie I have seen.)
- Mi hermana es **la mayor** de la familia. (My sister is the oldest in the family.)

### Absolute Superlative: -ísimo/a
The absolute superlative expresses an extreme degree without comparison ("very, extremely").

**Remove final vowel + -ísimo/a/os/as**:
| Adjective | Absolute Superlative | English |
|---|---|---|
| rápido | rapid**ísimo** | extremely fast |
| fácil | facil**ísimo** | extremely easy |
| grande | grand**ísimo** | extremely big |
| bueno | buen**ísimo** | extremely good |
| rico | riqu**ísimo** | extremely tasty (c→qu) |
| largo | largu**ísimo** | extremely long (g→gu) |

### muy vs -ísimo
Both express "very" but -ísimo is more emphatic:
- Es **muy** difícil. = It's very difficult.
- Es **dificilísimo**. = It's extremely difficult.

**Important**: Never combine muy + -ísimo. Do NOT say *muy facilísimo*.

### Example Sentences
- Este es **el edificio más alto de** la ciudad. (This is the tallest building in the city.)
- La comida está **buenísima**. (The food is extremely good.)
- Es **el mejor** día de mi vida. (It is the best day of my life.)
key_points: Relative superlative: el/la/los/las + más/menos + adj + de: la más grande de España
Irregular: el mejor (best), el peor (worst), el mayor (oldest), el menor (youngest)
Absolute superlative: -ísimo/a for 'extremely': rapidísimo, facilísimo
Never combine muy + -ísimo; use de (not en) after superlatives

ch_gram_a2_16.title: Affirmative Commands (tú)
ch_gram_a2_16.theory:
## Affirmative Commands: tú Form

The imperative mood is used to give **commands, instructions, or advice**. The informal (tú) affirmative command is one of the most commonly used forms.

### Regular Formation
The regular tú affirmative command is the same as the **3rd person singular (él/ella) present tense**:

| Infinitive | Present (él) | Command (tú) | English |
|---|---|---|---|
| hablar | habla | **¡Habla!** | Speak! |
| comer | come | **¡Come!** | Eat! |
| escribir | escribe | **¡Escribe!** | Write! |
| estudiar | estudia | **¡Estudia!** | Study! |
| abrir | abre | **¡Abre!** | Open! |

### Irregular tú Commands (8 Key Verbs)
These eight common verbs have special one-syllable command forms:

| Verb | Command | Mnemonic |
|---|---|---|
| **poner** | **pon** | put |
| **salir** | **sal** | leave/go out |
| **venir** | **ven** | come |
| **tener** | **ten** | have |
| **hacer** | **haz** | do/make |
| **decir** | **di** | say/tell |
| **ser** | **sé** | be |
| **ir** | **ve** | go |

Memory trick: **Pon Sal Ven Ten Haz Di Sé Ve** — imagine telling someone to "put salt, come, have, do, say, be, go!"

### Pronoun Attachment
With affirmative commands, pronouns **attach to the end** of the verb:
- ¡Cóme**lo**! (Eat it!)
- ¡Dí**me**! (Tell me!)
- ¡Siénta**te**! (Sit down!)
- ¡Escríbe**le**! (Write to him/her!)

### Accent Rules
When adding a pronoun makes the word 3+ syllables, add an accent to maintain the original stress:
- ¡Compra! → ¡Cómpr**a**lo! (Buy it!) — accent added
- ¡Come! → ¡Cóm**e**lo! (Eat it!) — accent added
- ¡Di! → ¡Dime! (Tell me!) — no accent needed (still 2 syllables)

### Example Sentences
- **¡Habla** más despacio! (Speak more slowly!)
- **¡Ven** aquí! (Come here!)
- **¡Haz** tu tarea! (Do your homework!)
- **¡Dime** la verdad! (Tell me the truth!)
key_points: Regular tú commands = 3rd person singular present: habla, come, escribe
8 irregular commands: pon, sal, ven, ten, haz, di, sé, ve
Pronouns attach to the end: ¡Cómelo! ¡Dime! ¡Siéntate!
Add accent marks when pronoun attachment creates 3+ syllables: cómpralo

ch_gram_a2_17.title: Por vs Para (Basics)
ch_gram_a2_17.theory:
## Por vs Para: Basic Uses

Both **por** and **para** can translate to English "for," but they are used in very different situations. This is one of the trickiest distinctions in Spanish.

### Para — Destination, Purpose, Deadline, Recipient

| Use | Example | English |
|---|---|---|
| **Destination** | Salgo **para** Madrid. | I leave for Madrid. |
| **Purpose (in order to)** | Estudio **para** aprender. | I study in order to learn. |
| **Deadline** | Es **para** el lunes. | It's for (due) Monday. |
| **Recipient** | El regalo es **para** ti. | The gift is for you. |
| **Opinion** | **Para** mí, es fácil. | For me (in my opinion), it's easy. |
| **Comparison** | **Para** ser niño, cocina bien. | For a child, he cooks well. |

### Por — Reason, Exchange, Duration, Movement Through

| Use | Example | English |
|---|---|---|
| **Reason/Cause** | Lo hago **por** ti. | I do it because of you. |
| **Exchange** | Pago diez euros **por** el libro. | I pay ten euros for the book. |
| **Duration** | Estudio **por** dos horas. | I study for two hours. |
| **Movement through** | Camino **por** el parque. | I walk through the park. |
| **Time of day** | Estudio **por** la mañana. | I study in the morning. |
| **Means** | Hablo **por** teléfono. | I speak by phone. |

### Fixed Expressions
| Expression | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **por favor** | please |
| **gracias por** | thanks for |
| **por ejemplo** | for example |
| **por eso** | that's why |
| **por supuesto** | of course |
| **por fin** | finally |
| **para siempre** | forever |
| **para nada** | not at all |

### Key Contrasts
- Estudio **para** el examen. (I study for the exam.) — purpose/goal
- Estudio **por** la mañana. (I study in the morning.) — time period
- Camino **para** la escuela. (I walk toward the school.) — destination
- Camino **por** la escuela. (I walk through/around the school.) — movement through
- Lo hago **para** ti. (I do it for you.) — recipient/beneficiary
- Lo hago **por** ti. (I do it because of you.) — reason/motivation
key_points: Para = destination, purpose, deadline, recipient, opinion
Por = reason, exchange, duration, movement through, time of day, means
Key contrast: para ti (for you as recipient) vs por ti (because of you)
Fixed expressions: por favor, gracias por, por eso, para siempre

ch_gram_a2_18.title: Negation & Negative Pronouns
ch_gram_a2_18.theory:
## Negation and Negative Pronouns

Spanish has a rich set of negative words. A key difference from English is that **double negatives are not only allowed but required** in many cases.

### Negative Words
| Affirmative | Negative | English |
|---|---|---|
| **algo** (something) | **nada** (nothing) | nothing/anything |
| **alguien** (someone) | **nadie** (nobody) | nobody/anybody |
| **siempre** (always) | **nunca / jamás** (never) | never/ever |
| **alguno/a** (some) | **ninguno/a** (none) | none/not any |
| **también** (also) | **tampoco** (neither) | neither/not either |
| **o...o** (either...or) | **ni...ni** (neither...nor) | neither...nor |

### Double Negative Rule
When a negative word comes **after the verb**, you MUST add **no** before the verb:
- **No** tengo **nada**. (I don't have anything. / I have nothing.)
- **No** viene **nadie**. (Nobody is coming.)
- **No** como **nunca** carne. (I never eat meat.)
- **No** tengo **ningún** amigo aquí. (I don't have any friend here.)

### Negative Before the Verb (No Double Negative)
When a negative word comes **before the verb**, no "no" is needed:
- **Nada** es perfecto. (Nothing is perfect.)
- **Nadie** habla. (Nobody speaks.)
- **Nunca** estudio de noche. (I never study at night.)
- **Tampoco** me gusta. (I don't like it either.)

### Ninguno/a — Special Rules
- **Ninguno** shortens to **ningún** before masculine singular nouns: **ningún** libro (no book)
- Almost always used in **singular** (even when the English equivalent is plural): No tengo **ningún** amigo. (I don't have any friends.)
- **Ninguna** before feminine singular nouns: **ninguna** idea (no idea)

### ni...ni (neither...nor)
- **No** me gusta **ni** el café **ni** el té. (I like neither coffee nor tea.)
- **Ni** Pedro **ni** María vinieron. (Neither Pedro nor María came.)

### tampoco (neither / not either)
- No me gusta. — A mí **tampoco**. (I don't like it. — Me neither.)
- **Tampoco** quiero ir. (I don't want to go either.)

### nunca vs jamás
Both mean "never." **Jamás** is more emphatic. Together: **nunca jamás** = never ever.
- **Nunca** he estado en Japón. (I have never been to Japan.)
- ¡**Jamás**! (Never! / No way!)
key_points: Double negatives are required when negative word follows the verb: No tengo nada
Negative before verb needs no 'no': Nadie viene, Nunca estudio
ninguno → ningún before masculine nouns; almost always singular
tampoco = neither/not either; ni...ni = neither...nor

ch_gram_a2_19.title: Relative Pronoun que (Basics)
ch_gram_a2_19.theory:
## The Relative Pronoun 'que'

The word **que** is the most common relative pronoun in Spanish. It connects two clauses and can mean **"that," "which," or "who"** depending on context.

### Basic Usage
**Que** joins a main clause with a relative clause that gives more information about a noun:
- El libro **que** leo es bueno. (The book **that** I am reading is good.)
- La chica **que** habla es mi amiga. (The girl **who** is speaking is my friend.)
- El restaurante **que** me gusta está cerca. (The restaurant **that** I like is nearby.)

### que = that / which / who
- **For things**: La película **que** vimos es interesante. (The movie **that** we watched is interesting.)
- **For people**: El profesor **que** enseña español es de México. (The teacher **who** teaches Spanish is from Mexico.)

### que Is NEVER Omitted
Unlike English, where "that" can often be dropped, Spanish **always requires que**:
- The book **(that)** I bought → El libro **que** compré (never *El libro compré)
- The person **(that)** I saw → La persona **que** vi (never *La persona vi)

### que After Prepositions
When a preposition is needed, it goes **before que**, and the article (el/la/los/las) is added:
- La casa **en la que** vivo es pequeña. (The house **in which** I live is small.)
- El chico **con el que** hablo es mi primo. (The boy **with whom** I am talking is my cousin.)
- La empresa **para la que** trabajo es grande. (The company **for which** I work is large.)

### lo que (what / the thing that)
**Lo que** refers to an idea or something unspecified:
- **Lo que** dices es verdad. (What you say is true.)
- No entiendo **lo que** quieres. (I don't understand what you want.)
- **Lo que** más me gusta es viajar. (What I like most is traveling.)

### Common Patterns
- Es la persona **que** me ayudó. (It's the person who helped me.)
- Todo **lo que** necesitas está aquí. (Everything that you need is here.)
- La razón **por la que** llamo es... (The reason for which I'm calling is...)
key_points: que = that/which/who — the most common relative pronoun in Spanish
que is NEVER omitted in Spanish (unlike English): El libro que compré
With prepositions, add article: en el que, con la que, para los que
lo que = what / the thing that: Lo que dices es verdad

vocab_list.example_meaning: The book that I am reading is very interesting.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I don't understand what you are saying.

ch_gram_a2_20.title: Combined Object Pronouns
ch_gram_a2_20.theory:
## Combined Object Pronouns

When a verb has both an **indirect object pronoun (IOP)** and a **direct object pronoun (DOP)**, they can appear together. The order is always **IOP + DOP**.

### The Order: IOP Before DOP
| IOP | + | DOP |
|---|---|---|
| me | | lo, la, los, las |
| te | | lo, la, los, las |
| nos | | lo, la, los, las |
| os | | lo, la, los, las |

### Examples
- ¿**Me** das el libro? → ¿**Me lo** das? (Will you give it to me?)
- **Te** compro las flores. → **Te las** compro. (I buy them for you.)
- **Nos** explica la lección. → **Nos la** explica. (He explains it to us.)

### The le/les → se Rule
When **le** or **les** (3rd person IOP) comes before **lo/la/los/las** (DOP), **le/les changes to se**:
- **Le** doy el libro. → ***Le lo** doy. ✗ → **Se lo** doy. ✓ (I give it to him/her.)
- **Les** compro las flores. → ***Les las** compro. ✗ → **Se las** compro. ✓ (I buy them for them.)

**Important**: Since **se** can mean "to him/her/you/them," add **a él/ella/usted/ellos/ellas/ustedes** for clarity:
- **Se lo** doy **a ella**. (I give it to her.)
- **Se las** compro **a ellos**. (I buy them for them.)

### Position of Combined Pronouns
Both pronouns go together — they are never separated:

1. **Before conjugated verb**: **Me lo** da. (He gives it to me.)
2. **Attached to infinitive**: Va a dár**melo**. OR **Me lo** va a dar.
3. **Attached to gerund**: Está explicándo**nosla**. OR **Nos la** está explicando.
4. **Attached to affirmative command**: ¡Dá**melo**! (Give it to me!)
5. **Before negative command**: ¡No **me lo** des! (Don't give it to me!)

### Accent Marks
When two pronouns attach to a verb, an accent is usually needed:
- dar + me + lo = dár**melo** (3 syllables before stress → accent)
- diciendo + se + lo = diciéndo**selo**
- ¡Compra + se + lo = ¡Cómpra**selo**!

### Summary Table
| Full Sentence | With Pronouns |
|---|---|
| Doy el libro a María. | **Se lo** doy. |
| Compras las flores para mí. | **Me las** compras. |
| Explica la lección a nosotros. | **Nos la** explica. |
| Digo la verdad a ti. | **Te la** digo. |
key_points: Order is always IOP + DOP: me lo, te la, nos los
le/les + lo/la/los/las → se lo, se la, se los, se las (le/les becomes se)
Clarify se with 'a él/ella/usted/ellos': Se lo doy a ella
Both pronouns stay together: before verb or both attached to infinitive/gerund/command

ch_vocab_a2_01.title: Travel & Vacation
ch_vocab_a2_01.theory:
## Travel Vocabulary

Traveling is one of the most practical situations where you need Spanish. Let's learn the key vocabulary for airports, hotels, and travel planning.

### At the Airport (En el aeropuerto)
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **el aeropuerto** | airport |
| **el vuelo** | flight |
| **el equipaje** | luggage |
| **la maleta** | suitcase |
| **el pasaporte** | passport |
| **el billete / el boleto** | ticket |
| **la tarjeta de embarque** | boarding pass |
| **facturar** | to check in (luggage) |
| **embarcar** | to board |

### At the Hotel (En el hotel)
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **el hotel** | hotel |
| **la habitación** | room |
| **la reserva** | reservation |
| **reservar** | to reserve / book |
| **la llave / tarjeta** | key / key card |

### Useful Travel Phrases
- **¿Tiene habitación libre?** — Do you have a room available?
- **Quisiera reservar una habitación doble.** — I would like to book a double room.
- **El vuelo sale a las ocho.** — The flight leaves at eight.
- **¿Dónde está la puerta de embarque?** — Where is the boarding gate?
- **Necesito facturar mi equipaje.** — I need to check in my luggage.

### billete vs boleto
In Spain, people say **el billete** for ticket, while in Latin America, **el boleto** is more common. Both are correct and widely understood.
key_points: el aeropuerto, el vuelo, el equipaje — essential airport words
billete (Spain) vs boleto (Latin America) — both mean ticket
Quisiera reservar... — polite way to make a reservation
facturar = to check in luggage, embarcar = to board

ch_vocab_a2_02.title: Health & Hospital
ch_vocab_a2_02.theory:
## Health Vocabulary

Knowing how to describe health problems is essential, especially when visiting a doctor or pharmacy in a Spanish-speaking country.

### Medical Places and People
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **el médico / el doctor** | doctor |
| **la enfermera** | nurse |
| **el hospital** | hospital |
| **la farmacia** | pharmacy |
| **la consulta** | doctor's office / appointment |

### Symptoms and Illnesses
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **la fiebre** | fever |
| **el dolor** | pain |
| **la gripe** | flu |
| **el resfriado** | cold |
| **la tos** | cough |

### Medicine
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **la receta** | prescription |
| **la pastilla / la medicina** | pill / medicine |
| **recetar** | to prescribe |
| **toser** | to cough |
| **estornudar** | to sneeze |

### Using 'doler' (to hurt)
The verb **doler** works like **gustar** — the body part is the subject:
- **Me duele la cabeza.** — My head hurts. (lit. The head hurts to me.)
- **Me duele el estómago.** — My stomach hurts.
- **Me duelen las piernas.** — My legs hurt. (plural → duelen)

### Useful Phrases at the Doctor
- **Tengo fiebre / tos / gripe.** — I have a fever / cough / flu.
- **Necesito ir al médico.** — I need to go to the doctor.
- **¿Qué le pasa?** — What's wrong with you? (formal)
- **Tiene que tomar esta medicina tres veces al día.** — You have to take this medicine three times a day.
key_points: doler works like gustar: Me duele la cabeza (my head hurts)
Use duele (singular) or duelen (plural) depending on the body part
Tengo fiebre/tos/gripe — use tener for symptoms
la receta = prescription, recetar = to prescribe

vocab_list.example_meaning: I need to go to the doctor, I feel bad.

vocab_list.example_meaning: I bought the pills at the pharmacy.

ch_vocab_a2_03.title: Sports & Hobbies
ch_vocab_a2_03.theory:
## Sports and Hobbies Vocabulary

Talking about sports and hobbies is a great way to connect with people. Spanish uses specific verbs depending on the activity.

### Common Sports (Deportes comunes)
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **el fútbol** | soccer / football |
| **el baloncesto** | basketball |
| **la natación** | swimming |
| **el tenis** | tennis |
| **el ciclismo** | cycling |

### Sports Verbs
| Verb | Usage |
|---|---|
| **jugar a** | for team/ball sports: jugar al fútbol |
| **practicar** | for general sports: practicar natación |
| **correr** | to run |
| **nadar** | to swim |

### Hobbies (Pasatiempos)
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **pintar** | to paint |
| **cocinar** | to cook |
| **bailar** | to dance |
| **leer** | to read |
| **tocar (un instrumento)** | to play (an instrument) |

### jugar vs practicar vs tocar
- **Jugar a** + team/ball sport: Juego **al** fútbol. (I play soccer.)
- **Practicar** + individual sport: Practico **natación**. (I practice swimming.)
- **Tocar** + instrument: Toco **la guitarra**. (I play guitar.)

### Using gustar/encantar with Hobbies
- **Me gusta pintar.** — I like to paint.
- **Me encanta bailar.** — I love to dance.
- **Mi pasatiempo favorito es cocinar.** — My favorite hobby is cooking.

### Competition Words
- **el equipo** — team
- **el partido** — match / game
- **ganar** — to win
- **perder** — to lose
key_points: jugar al + team sport (fútbol), practicar + individual sport (natación)
tocar + instrument: Toco la guitarra (I play guitar)
