ch_gram_b2_10.title: Discourse Connectors
ch_gram_b2_10.theory:
## Discourse Connectors (Conectores del Discurso)

Discourse connectors are words and phrases that **link ideas, sentences, and paragraphs** to create coherent and fluent text. Mastering them is essential for B2-level writing and speaking.

### Adding Information
| Connector | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **además** | moreover / besides / in addition |
| **también** | also |
| **asimismo** | likewise / also (formal) |
| **incluso** | even |
| **es más** | what's more |
| **aparte de** | apart from |
| **no solo... sino también** | not only... but also |

### Contrasting Ideas
| Connector | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **sin embargo** | however |
| **no obstante** | nevertheless |
| **en cambio** | on the other hand / instead |
| **por el contrario** | on the contrary |
| **a pesar de (que)** | despite (the fact that) |
| **aunque** | although / even though |
| **mientras que** | while / whereas |

### Cause and Reason
| Connector | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **porque** | because |
| **ya que** | since / given that |
| **puesto que** | since / given that (formal) |
| **dado que** | given that |
| **debido a (que)** | due to (the fact that) |
| **como** | since / as (at beginning of sentence) |

### Consequence and Result
| Connector | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **por eso** | that's why / therefore |
| **por lo tanto** | therefore |
| **así que** | so |
| **de modo que** | so that / in such a way that |
| **en consecuencia** | consequently |
| **de ahí que** + subjunctive | hence / that's why |

### Purpose
| Connector | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **para (que)** | in order to / so that |
| **con el fin de (que)** | with the aim of |
| **a fin de (que)** | in order to |

### Organizing Discourse
| Connector | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **en primer lugar** | in the first place |
| **por un lado... por otro (lado)** | on the one hand... on the other |
| **en cuanto a** | as for / regarding |
| **respecto a** | with respect to |
| **por último** | lastly |
| **en resumen** | in summary |
| **en conclusión** | in conclusion |

### Examples in Context
- **Además**, el precio incluye el desayuno. — Moreover, the price includes breakfast.
- Estudia mucho; **sin embargo**, no aprueba. — He studies a lot; however, he doesn't pass.
- **Ya que** estás aquí, ayúdame. — Since you're here, help me.
- Llovía mucho, **por lo tanto** nos quedamos en casa. — It was raining a lot, therefore we stayed home.
- **En primer lugar**, quiero agradecer a todos. — In the first place, I want to thank everyone.
key_points: Sin embargo / no obstante = however/nevertheless (contrast)
Ya que / puesto que / dado que = since/given that (cause, more formal than porque)
Por lo tanto / en consecuencia = therefore/consequently (result)
De ahí que always requires the subjunctive
En primer lugar, por un lado/por otro, en conclusión help organize discourse

vocab_list.example: Es caro; sin embargo, merece la pena.
vocab_list.example_meaning: It's expensive; however, it's worth it.

vocab_list.example: Ya que no vienes, iré solo.
vocab_list.example_meaning: Since you're not coming, I'll go alone.

vocab_list.example: No estudió, por lo tanto suspendió.
vocab_list.example_meaning: He didn't study, therefore he failed.

vocab_list.example: Es inteligente y, además, muy trabajadora.
vocab_list.example_meaning: She's intelligent and, moreover, very hard-working.

ch_gram_b2_11.title: Verbal Periphrasis
ch_gram_b2_11.theory:
## Verbal Periphrasis (Perífrasis Verbales)

A verbal periphrasis is a **combination of two or more verbs** that function as a single unit, where the first verb (auxiliary) is conjugated and the second is in a non-finite form (infinitive, gerund, or participle). They express nuances like obligation, probability, continuity, and phases of an action.

### Periphrasis with Infinitive

| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **ir a** + inf. | to be going to | Voy a estudiar. |
| **tener que** + inf. | to have to (obligation) | Tengo que salir. |
| **hay que** + inf. | one must (impersonal) | Hay que estudiar más. |
| **deber** + inf. | must / should (obligation) | Debes llegar a tiempo. |
| **deber de** + inf. | must (probability) | Debe de estar en casa. |
| **poder** + inf. | to be able to / can | Puedo ayudarte. |
| **soler** + inf. | to usually do | Suelo correr por las mañanas. |
| **volver a** + inf. | to do again | Volvió a llamar. |
| **dejar de** + inf. | to stop doing | Dejó de fumar. |
| **acabar de** + inf. | to have just done | Acabo de llegar. |
| **ponerse a** + inf. | to start (suddenly) | Se puso a llover. |
| **echarse a** + inf. | to burst into | Se echó a llorar. |
| **llegar a** + inf. | to manage to / to end up | Llegó a ser presidente. |

### Periphrasis with Gerund

| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **estar** + gerund | to be doing (progressive) | Estoy estudiando. |
| **seguir / continuar** + gerund | to keep on doing | Sigue lloviendo. |
| **llevar** + time + gerund | to have been doing for | Llevo dos horas esperando. |
| **ir** + gerund | to gradually do | Va mejorando poco a poco. |
| **andar** + gerund | to go around doing | Anda buscando trabajo. |

### Periphrasis with Participle

| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **tener** + participle | to have (result state) | Tengo hechos los deberes. |
| **llevar** + participle | to have (accumulated) | Llevo leídos tres capítulos. |
| **dejar** + participle | to leave in a state | Dejó la puerta cerrada. |

### Deber vs Deber de
This is an important distinction at B2:
- **Deber + infinitive** = obligation: **Debes** estudiar. (You must study.)
- **Deber de + infinitive** = probability: **Debe de** ser tarde. (It must be late.)

In practice, many speakers confuse them, but in formal writing the distinction matters.

### Llevar + Time + Gerund
This structure has no direct English equivalent and is very useful:
- **Llevo tres años viviendo** aquí. — I've been living here for three years.
- **¿Cuánto tiempo llevas estudiando** español? — How long have you been studying Spanish?
key_points: Verbal periphrasis = conjugated auxiliary + infinitive/gerund/participle
Deber + inf. = obligation; deber de + inf. = probability
Llevar + time + gerund expresses duration: Llevo dos horas esperando
Volver a + inf. = to do again; dejar de + inf. = to stop doing; acabar de + inf. = to have just done
Ponerse a / echarse a + inf. express sudden beginning of an action

ch_gram_b2_12.title: Passive Se Construction
ch_gram_b2_12.theory:
## Passive Se Construction (La Pasiva con Se / Se Pasivo)

Spanish has multiple ways to express passive meaning. The **passive se** construction is the most common in everyday speech, far more frequent than the traditional passive voice (ser + past participle).

### Formation

**Se + verb (3rd person) + subject**

The verb agrees with the grammatical subject (the thing being acted upon):
- **Se vende** esta casa. — This house is for sale. (singular)
- **Se venden** estas casas. — These houses are for sale. (plural)
- **Se habla** español aquí. — Spanish is spoken here.
- **Se hablan** tres idiomas. — Three languages are spoken.

### Key Uses

1. **General statements (no specific agent)**:
   - En España **se cena** tarde. — In Spain, dinner is eaten late.
   - **Se dice** que va a llover. — It is said that it's going to rain.

2. **Signs and advertisements**:
   - **Se alquila** piso. — Apartment for rent.
   - **Se busca** camarero. — Waiter wanted.
   - **Se necesitan** voluntarios. — Volunteers needed.

3. **Rules, instructions, and processes**:
   - **Se mezclan** los ingredientes. — The ingredients are mixed.
   - Primero **se corta** la cebolla. — First the onion is cut.

### Passive Se vs Impersonal Se

Both use **se** but have different structures:

| Type | Structure | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **Passive se** | Se + verb (agrees with subject) | Se vende**n** coches. (Cars are sold.) |
| **Impersonal se** | Se + verb (3rd person singular only) | Se vive bien aquí. (One lives well here.) |

**Impersonal se** is used when:
- The verb is intransitive: **Se vive** bien. (One lives well.)
- The object is a person (with **a**): **Se entrevistó a** los candidatos. (The candidates were interviewed.)

### Passive Se vs Ser + Past Participle

| Construction | Use | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **Passive se** | Unknown/unimportant agent, everyday speech | Se construyó el puente en 2010. |
| **Ser + participle** | Agent is mentioned, formal/journalistic | El puente fue construido por el gobierno. |

### Common Pitfall
With people as the object, use impersonal se (singular verb + **a**):
- **Se entrevistó a** los candidatos. (NOT ~~Se entrevistaron los candidatos.~~)
- **Se ayudó a** los refugiados. (NOT ~~Se ayudaron los refugiados.~~)
key_points: Passive se: Se + verb (agrees with subject noun) — Se venden coches
Impersonal se: Se + 3rd person singular verb — Se vive bien aquí
With human objects use impersonal se + a: Se entrevistó a los candidatos
Passive se is far more common in speech than ser + past participle
The verb must agree in number with the subject: Se vende (sg.) vs Se venden (pl.)

ch_gram_b2_13.title: Subjunctive in Adjective Clauses
ch_gram_b2_13.theory:
## Subjunctive in Adjective Clauses (Cláusulas Adjetivas / De Relativo)

Adjective clauses (also called relative clauses) describe or modify a noun. The choice between **indicative** and **subjunctive** in these clauses depends on whether the noun being described is **known/existing** or **unknown/non-existent/hypothetical**.

### The Rule

| Antecedent | Mood | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **Known / Existing** | Indicative | Tengo un amigo que **habla** chino. |
| **Unknown / Sought** | Subjunctive | Busco un amigo que **hable** chino. |
| **Non-existent / Denied** | Subjunctive | No hay nadie que **hable** chino aquí. |

### Detailed Examples

**Known antecedent → Indicative:**
- Conozco a un profesor que **enseña** muy bien. — I know a teacher who teaches very well. (I know this specific person.)
- Tenemos un apartamento que **tiene** tres habitaciones. — We have an apartment that has three bedrooms.

**Unknown/sought antecedent → Subjunctive:**
- Necesito un profesor que **enseñe** bien. — I need a teacher who teaches well. (I haven't found one yet.)
- Buscamos un apartamento que **tenga** tres habitaciones. — We're looking for an apartment that has three bedrooms.
- ¿Conoces a alguien que **sepa** programar? — Do you know someone who knows how to code?

**Non-existent antecedent → Subjunctive:**
- No hay ningún restaurante que **sirva** comida mexicana. — There is no restaurant that serves Mexican food.
- No conozco a nadie que **haya estado** en la Antártida. — I don't know anyone who has been to Antarctica.

### Key Triggers for Subjunctive
- **Buscar** (to look for) + unknown: Busco algo que **sea** barato.
- **Necesitar** (to need) + unknown: Necesito alguien que **pueda** ayudarme.
- **Querer** (to want) + unknown: Quiero un coche que **consuma** poco.
- **No hay** / **No existe** + negated: No hay nada que **podamos** hacer.
- **¿Hay...?** / **¿Conoces...?** + uncertain: ¿Hay alguien que **sepa** la respuesta?

### Indicative vs Subjunctive — Meaning Change
- Busco **al** secretario que **habla** inglés. — I'm looking for the secretary who speaks English. (I know who he is; specific person with **al**.)
- Busco **un** secretario que **hable** inglés. — I'm looking for a secretary who speaks English. (Any secretary with that skill; indefinite **un**.)

Notice how the article (**al** vs **un**) and the mood work together to signal specificity.
key_points: Known/existing antecedent → indicative: Tengo un amigo que habla chino
Unknown/sought antecedent → subjunctive: Busco un amigo que hable chino
Non-existent antecedent → subjunctive: No hay nadie que sepa
The definite article (el/la) usually signals indicative; indefinite (un/una) may signal subjunctive
Key trigger verbs: buscar, necesitar, querer + undefined noun

ch_gram_b2_14.title: Hypothetical Comparisons
ch_gram_b2_14.theory:
## Hypothetical Comparisons (Comparaciones Hipotéticas)

Hypothetical comparisons express **unreal or imaginary** comparisons. They use structures like **como si**, **cual si**, and **igual que si**, all of which require the **subjunctive**.

### Como si + Subjunctive

The most common structure. **Como si** (as if) is always followed by the past subjunctive or pluperfect subjunctive — never the present subjunctive or indicative.

| Timeframe | Structure | Example |
|---|---|---|
| Same time as main verb | como si + past subjunctive | Habla **como si supiera** todo. |
| Before the main verb | como si + pluperfect subjunctive | Habla **como si hubiera vivido** allí. |

### Detailed Examples

**Como si + past subjunctive (simultaneous/general):**
- Gasta dinero **como si fuera** millonario. — He spends money as if he were a millionaire.
- Me mira **como si no me conociera**. — She looks at me as if she didn't know me.
- Actúan **como si no pasara** nada. — They act as if nothing were happening.

**Como si + pluperfect subjunctive (prior action):**
- Hablaba del tema **como si hubiera estudiado** durante años. — He talked about the topic as if he had studied for years.
- Se comportó **como si no hubiera pasado** nada. — He behaved as if nothing had happened.

### Other Hypothetical Comparison Structures

1. **Igual que si** + subjunctive (same as como si, less common):
   - Lo dijo **igual que si fuera** una broma. — He said it just as if it were a joke.

2. **Como para** + infinitive (as if to / enough to):
   - No es **como para** preocuparse. — It's not something to worry about.
   - Hacía un frío **como para** no salir de casa. — It was cold enough to not leave the house.

3. **Parecer que** / **Parece como si**:
   - **Parece como si fuera** a llover. — It looks as if it's going to rain.
   - **Parece que hubiera** llovido. — It looks like it rained.

### Tense Sequence Summary

| Main Verb Tense | Como si + ... |
|---|---|
| Present | past subjunctive: Habla como si **supiera**. |
| Preterite | past subjunctive or pluperfect subj.: Habló como si **supiera** / **hubiera sabido**. |
| Imperfect | past subjunctive or pluperfect subj.: Hablaba como si **supiera**. |

### Common Pitfall
**Never use the present subjunctive or indicative after como si:**
- ~~como si sabe~~ → como si **supiera**
- ~~como si puede~~ → como si **pudiera**
key_points: Como si always requires past subjunctive or pluperfect subjunctive — never indicative or present subjunctive
Past subjunctive after como si for simultaneous actions; pluperfect for prior actions
Parece como si + subjunctive = 'It looks as if...'
Como para + infinitive expresses 'enough to' or 'as if to'
The tense of the main verb does not change the mood requirement after como si

ch_gram_b2_15.title: Emphatic Constructions
ch_gram_b2_15.theory:
## Emphatic Constructions (Construcciones Enfáticas)

Emphatic constructions allow you to **highlight or stress** a particular element of a sentence. Spanish has several strategies for emphasis that differ from English.

### 1. Cleft Sentences with Ser (Oraciones Hendidas)

These use **ser** to focus attention on one element:

**Es/Fue + focused element + el/la que / quien / donde / cuando...**

- **Fue María la que** me llamó. — It was María who called me.
- **Es aquí donde** vivo. — It is here where I live.
- **Fue ayer cuando** lo vi. — It was yesterday when I saw him.
- **Es a ti a quien** busco. — It is you whom I'm looking for.

### 2. Lo que... es/fue (Pseudo-cleft)

This construction fronts the information for emphasis:

- **Lo que** necesito **es** descansar. — What I need is to rest.
- **Lo que** me molesta **es** su actitud. — What bothers me is his attitude.
- **Lo que** hizo **fue** salir corriendo. — What he did was run out.

### 3. Sí que (emphatic affirmation)

**Sí que** strongly affirms something, often contradicting a previous statement:

- — No estudiaste. — You didn't study.
- — **Sí que** estudié. — I DID study.
- **Sí que** es caro este restaurante. — This restaurant IS expensive.

### 4. Emphatic Pronoun Placement

Placing a pronoun at the beginning or using a prepositional pronoun for emphasis:

- **A mí** me gusta el chocolate. — I like chocolate. (emphasis on "I")
- **A él** no le importa. — He doesn't care. (emphasis on "he")
- Eso lo sé **yo**. — I know that. (emphasis on "I")

### 5. Ser + quien/el que for Agent Emphasis

- **Yo fui quien** lo hizo. / **Yo fui el que** lo hizo. — I was the one who did it.
- **Tú eres la que** siempre llega tarde. — You are the one who always arrives late.

### 6. Reduplication for Emphasis

Repeating words intensifies meaning:
- Está **lejos, lejos**. — It's far, far away.
- Lo hizo **bien, bien**. — He did it really well.

### 7. Pero si... (surprise/emphasis)

Expresses surprise or reinforcement:
- **Pero si** acabo de llegar. — But I just got here!
- **Pero si** eso ya lo sabías. — But you already knew that!
key_points: Cleft sentences: Fue María la que me llamó (It was María who called me)
Lo que... es/fue: Lo que necesito es descansar (What I need is to rest)
Sí que emphasizes affirmation, often contradicting: Sí que estudié (I DID study)
Prepositional pronouns for emphasis: A mí me gusta, A él no le importa
Pero si expresses surprise or reinforcement: Pero si acabo de llegar!

ch_gram_b2_16.title: Sino vs Pero
ch_gram_b2_16.theory:
## Sino vs Pero — When to Use Each

Both **pero** and **sino** translate to "but" in English, but they are used in different contexts and are **not interchangeable**.

### Pero (But — adds contrasting information)

**Pero** introduces information that **contrasts with but does not contradict** the first clause:

- Es caro, **pero** es bueno. — It's expensive, but it's good.
- Estoy cansado, **pero** voy a seguir. — I'm tired, but I'm going to keep going.
- No es grande, **pero** es cómodo. — It's not big, but it's comfortable.

### Sino (But rather — corrects/replaces)

**Sino** is used after a **negative clause** to **correct or replace** the negated information:

- No es rojo, **sino** azul. — It's not red, but (rather) blue.
- No quiero café, **sino** té. — I don't want coffee, but (rather) tea.
- No vive en Madrid, **sino** en Barcelona. — He doesn't live in Madrid, but in Barcelona.

### Sino que (But rather — with conjugated verbs)

When the correction involves a **conjugated verb**, use **sino que**:

- No trabaja, **sino que** estudia. — He doesn't work, but (rather) studies.
- No me llamó, **sino que** me envió un mensaje. — He didn't call me, but sent me a message.
- No salió corriendo, **sino que** se quedó tranquilo. — He didn't run off, but stayed calm.

### No solo... sino (también) — Not only... but (also)

This correlative structure emphasizes addition after negation:

- **No solo** habla español, **sino también** francés. — He not only speaks Spanish but also French.
- **No solo** es inteligente, **sino que también** es amable. — She is not only intelligent but also kind.

### Decision Flowchart

1. Is the first clause negative AND the second clause **corrects/replaces** it?
   - **Yes** → Use **sino** (or **sino que** with a conjugated verb)
   - **No** → Use **pero**

### Tricky Cases

| Sentence | Connector | Why |
|---|---|---|
| No es fácil, **pero** es posible. | pero | Not replacing — adding new info |
| No es fácil, **sino** difícil. | sino | Replacing fácil with difícil |
| No come carne, **pero** come pescado. | pero | Not correcting — adding different info |
| No come carne, **sino** pescado. | sino | Replacing carne with pescado |

### Common Pitfall
- After an affirmative clause, always use **pero**, never **sino**:
  - ~~Es bonito sino caro~~ → Es bonito, **pero** caro.
- **Sino** can only follow a negative clause.
key_points: Pero adds contrasting information: Es caro, pero bueno
Sino corrects/replaces after a negative clause: No es rojo, sino azul
Sino que is used when the replacement involves a conjugated verb
No solo... sino también = not only... but also
Sino can ONLY follow a negative clause; pero can follow any clause

ch_gram_b2_17.title: Subjunctive Tense Agreement
ch_gram_b2_17.theory:
## Subjunctive Tense Agreement (Concordancia Temporal del Subjuntivo)

When a sentence requires the subjunctive in the subordinate clause, the **tense of the main verb** determines which **subjunctive tense** should be used in the dependent clause. This is called the **sequence of tenses** (concordancia temporal).

### The Two Spheres

Spanish divides tenses into two spheres:

| Sphere | Main Verb Tenses | Subjunctive Used |
|---|---|---|
| **Present sphere** | Present, Future, Present Perfect, Imperative | Present subjunctive / Present perfect subjunctive |
| **Past sphere** | Preterite, Imperfect, Conditional, Pluperfect | Past subjunctive / Pluperfect subjunctive |

### Present Sphere Examples

Main verb in present/future → subordinate uses **present subjunctive** or **present perfect subjunctive**:

- **Quiero** que **vengas**. — I want you to come.
- **Espero** que **hayas aprobado**. — I hope you have passed.
- **Le diré** que **traiga** la comida. — I'll tell him to bring the food.
- **Es importante** que **estudies**. — It's important that you study.

### Past Sphere Examples

Main verb in past/conditional → subordinate uses **past subjunctive** or **pluperfect subjunctive**:

- **Quería** que **vinieras**. — I wanted you to come.
- **Le pedí** que **trajera** la comida. — I asked him to bring the food.
- **Dudaba** que **hubieran aprobado**. — I doubted that they had passed.
- **Sería** mejor que **estudiaras**. — It would be better if you studied.
- **Era importante** que **estudiaran**. — It was important that they study.

### Complete Tense Agreement Table

| Main Clause Tense | Simultaneous/Future (subord.) | Prior (subord.) |
|---|---|---|
| Present: Quiero que... | **venga** (pres. subj.) | **haya venido** (pres. perf. subj.) |
| Preterite: Quise que... | **viniera** (past subj.) | **hubiera venido** (pluperf. subj.) |
| Imperfect: Quería que... | **viniera** (past subj.) | **hubiera venido** (pluperf. subj.) |
| Future: Querré que... | **venga** (pres. subj.) | **haya venido** (pres. perf. subj.) |
| Conditional: Querría que... | **viniera** (past subj.) | **hubiera venido** (pluperf. subj.) |

### Flexibility and Exceptions

In some cases, the sequence can be broken for emphasis or when the subordinate action has present relevance:

- **Me pidió** que le **llame** mañana. — He asked me to call him tomorrow. (Past main verb, but present subjunctive because the action is future.)
- **No creo** que **fuera** tan difícil. — I don't think it was that difficult. (Present main verb with past subjunctive referring to past events.)

These "broken" sequences are acceptable and common in real speech.

### Common Pitfall
Students often use the present subjunctive after a past main verb:
- ~~Quería que vengas~~ → Quería que **vinieras**.
- ~~Le pedí que traiga~~ → Le pedí que **trajera**.
key_points: Present sphere (present/future main verb) → present subjunctive: Quiero que vengas
Past sphere (past/conditional main verb) → past subjunctive: Quería que vinieras
For prior actions, use perfect forms: Espero que hayas venido / Dudaba que hubiera venido
Sequence can be broken when the subordinate action has present/future relevance
Common error: using present subjunctive after past main verb (Quería que vengas → vinieras)

ch_gram_b2_18.title: Preposition + Relative Pronoun
ch_gram_b2_18.theory:
## Preposition + Relative Pronoun (Preposición + Pronombre Relativo)

In Spanish, when a relative clause requires a preposition, the preposition must come **before** the relative pronoun — unlike English, where the preposition can go at the end of the sentence.

### English vs Spanish Word Order

| English (informal) | English (formal) | Spanish |
|---|---|---|
| The person I spoke **to** | The person **to** whom I spoke | La persona **con la que** hablé |
| The house I live **in** | The house **in** which I live | La casa **en la que** vivo |
| The reason I came **for** | The reason **for** which I came | La razón **por la que** vine |

### Structures with Prepositions

**Preposition + el/la/los/las que:**
- La empresa **para la que** trabajo es internacional. — The company I work for is international.
- El tema **sobre el que** hablamos es interesante. — The topic we talked about is interesting.
- Las personas **con las que** viajé son mis compañeros. — The people I traveled with are my colleagues.

**Preposition + quien(es)** (people only):
- La persona **con quien** hablé era amable. — The person I spoke with was kind.
- Los amigos **a quienes** invité no vinieron. — The friends I invited didn't come.

**Preposition + el/la cual, los/las cuales** (formal):
- El edificio **en el cual** vivimos es antiguo. — The building in which we live is old.
- La razón **por la cual** dimitió es desconocida. — The reason for which he resigned is unknown.

### Common Preposition + Relative Pronoun Combinations

| Combination | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **en el/la que** | in which | La ciudad en la que nací |
| **con el/la que** | with which/whom | El chico con el que salgo |
| **para el/la que** | for which/whom | El trabajo para el que estudié |
| **por el/la que** | for which / through which | La razón por la que vine |
| **del que / de la que** | of/from which | El libro del que te hablé |
| **al que / a la que** | to which | La fiesta a la que fuimos |
| **sin el/la que** | without which | La herramienta sin la que no puedo trabajar |
| **sobre el/la que** | about which | El tema sobre el que escribí |

### Donde, Adonde, Como, Cuando

Relative adverbs can sometimes replace preposition + relative pronoun:

- La ciudad **en la que** nací = La ciudad **donde** nací — The city where I was born.
- El lugar **al que** vamos = El lugar **adonde** vamos — The place where we're going.

### Common Pitfall: Stranded Prepositions
Spanish **never** strands prepositions at the end of a clause (unlike English):
- ~~La persona que hablé con~~ → La persona **con la que** hablé.
- ~~El libro que te hablé de~~ → El libro **del que** te hablé.

### Agreement
The article in **el/la/los/las que** must agree with the antecedent:
- El chico **con el que** salgo (masc. sg.)
- La chica **con la que** salgo (fem. sg.)
- Los amigos **con los que** salgo (masc. pl.)
- Las amigas **con las que** salgo (fem. pl.)
key_points: Prepositions always come BEFORE the relative pronoun in Spanish, never at the end
Preposition + el/la/los/las que is the most common structure
Preposition + quien(es) is used for people only
The article must agree in gender and number with the antecedent
Donde can replace en el/la que for places: La ciudad donde nací

ch_vocab_b2_01.title: Politics & Government
ch_vocab_b2_01.theory:
## Political and Government Vocabulary

At the B2 level, you should be able to discuss political systems, elections, and government policies with confidence. Spanish-speaking countries have diverse political structures, and understanding this vocabulary is essential for reading newspapers, following debates, and expressing opinions on public affairs.

### Government Institutions
| Spanish | English |

ch_vocab_b2_08.title: Idioms (Modismos)
ch_vocab_b2_08.theory:
## Spanish Idioms (Modismos)

Idioms are fixed expressions whose meaning cannot be deduced from the individual words. Mastering Spanish idioms is a hallmark of B2-level proficiency and makes your speech sound natural and fluent.

### Idioms with Body Parts
| Idiom | Literal Meaning | Actual Meaning |
|---|---|---|
| **no tener pelos en la lengua** | not to have hairs on the tongue | to be outspoken / blunt |
| **meter la pata** | to put the paw in | to put one's foot in it / to blunder |
| **costar un ojo de la cara** | to cost an eye from the face | to cost an arm and a leg |
| **estar hasta las narices** | to be up to the noses | to be fed up |
| **tener mala cara** | to have a bad face | to look unwell |
| **dar la espalda** | to give the back | to turn one's back on |

### Idioms with Animals
| Idiom | Literal Meaning | Actual Meaning |
|---|---|---|
| **ser un buitre** | to be a vulture | to be an opportunist |
| **llevarse como el perro y el gato** | to get along like dog and cat | to fight like cats and dogs |
| **tener memoria de pez** | to have the memory of a fish | to have a terrible memory |
| **ser pan comido** | to be eaten bread | to be a piece of cake |

### Everyday Idioms
| Idiom | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **ir al grano** | to get to the point |
| **echar una mano** | to give a hand / help |
| **dar en el clavo** | to hit the nail on the head |
| **estar en las nubes** | to have one's head in the clouds |
| **no dar abasto** | to not be able to keep up |
| **tomar el pelo (a alguien)** | to pull someone's leg |
| **tirar la toalla** | to throw in the towel |
| **ponerse las pilas** | to get one's act together |
| **dar la lata** | to be a nuisance / pest |
| **quedarse en blanco** | to go blank (mind) |

### Usage in Context
- **Voy a ir al grano: necesitamos más dinero.** — I'll get to the point: we need more money.
- **¿Me echas una mano con la mudanza?** — Can you give me a hand with the move?
- **El examen me costó un ojo de la cara en horas de estudio.** — The exam cost me a fortune in study hours.
- **Juan siempre mete la pata en las reuniones.** — Juan always puts his foot in it during meetings.
- **Estoy hasta las narices del ruido de las obras.** — I'm fed up with the construction noise.

ch_vocab_b2_10.theory:
## Debate and Argumentation Vocabulary

At the B2 level, you should be able to participate in debates, present arguments, counter opposing views, and structure your reasoning persuasively. This vocabulary is essential for DELE B2 oral and written tasks.

### Presenting Your Position

| **en mi opinión / a mi juicio** | in my opinion |
| **desde mi punto de vista** | from my point of view |
| **considero que** | I consider that |
| **estoy convencido/a de que** | I am convinced that |
| **sostengo que** | I maintain that |
| **cabe destacar que** | it is worth noting that |
| **es evidente que** | it is evident that |

### Agreeing and Disagreeing
| Spanish | English |
|---|---|
| **estoy de acuerdo (con)** | I agree (with) |
| **coincido contigo en que** | I agree with you that |
| **tienes razón en que** | you are right that |
| **discrepo / no estoy de acuerdo** | I disagree |
| **respeto tu opinión, pero** | I respect your opinion, but |
| **me temo que no comparto esa visión** | I'm afraid I don't share that view |

### Building Arguments

|---|---|

### Concluding a Debate

## Nuances of Emotion Vocabulary

At the B2 level, you move beyond basic emotions (happy, sad, angry) to express more nuanced and specific feelings. This vocabulary allows you to describe emotional states with precision, which is essential for personal narratives, literature, and deep conversations.

| **agradecido/a** | grateful | thankful for something |

| **aliviado/a** | relieved | after worry or stress |
| **orgulloso/a** | proud | achievement-related |
| **ilusionado/a** | excited / hopeful | looking forward to something |
| **conmovido/a** | moved / touched | emotionally affected |

| **angustiado/a** | anguished / distressed | deep anxiety |

ch_gram_c1_01.title: Advanced Subjunctive Usage
ch_gram_c1_01.theory:
## Advanced Subjunctive Usage

At the C1 level, the subjunctive goes far beyond basic wish/emotion triggers. You must master subtle distinctions, rare triggers, and stylistic choices that differentiate proficient speakers from advanced ones.

### 1. Subjunctive After Concessive Clauses

Concessive clauses introduced by **aunque**, **a pesar de que**, **por más que**, **por mucho que** take the subjunctive when the speaker presents the information as hypothetical or irrelevant to the outcome.

| Indicative (known fact) | Subjunctive (hypothetical/irrelevant) |
|---|---|
| Aunque **llueve**, salimos. (Even though it IS raining, we go out.) | Aunque **llueva**, saldremos. (Even if it MIGHT rain, we'll go out.) |
| A pesar de que **tiene** dinero, no es feliz. | A pesar de que **tenga** dinero, no será feliz. |

### 2. Subjunctive in Relative Clauses

Use the subjunctive in relative clauses when the antecedent is **indefinite, nonexistent, or hypothetical**.

- **Busco a alguien que sepa chino.** — I'm looking for someone who knows Chinese. (not sure they exist)
- **No hay nadie que pueda ayudarme.** — There is nobody who can help me.
- **Necesitamos un programa que funcione mejor.** — We need a program that works better. (haven't found it yet)

Compare with indicative (known antecedent):
- **Conozco a alguien que sabe chino.** — I know someone who knows Chinese.

### 3. Subjunctive After Negative Expressions of Certainty

When expressions of certainty are negated, they trigger the subjunctive:

| Indicative (certainty) | Subjunctive (negated certainty) |
|---|---|
| Es cierto que **viene**. | No es cierto que **venga**. |
| Creo que **tiene** razón. | No creo que **tenga** razón. |
| Es evidente que **sabe**. | No es evidente que **sepa**. |

### 4. The Pluperfect Subjunctive in Counterfactuals

Used for past hypotheticals that did not happen:

- **Si hubiera sabido, habría ido.** — If I had known, I would have gone.
- **Ojalá hubieras estado allí.** — I wish you had been there.
- **Me habría gustado que hubieras venido.** — I would have liked you to have come.

### 5. Subjunctive in Fixed Expressions

| Expression | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **sea como sea** | be that as it may | Sea como sea, debemos continuar. |
| **pase lo que pase** | whatever happens | Pase lo que pase, te apoyaré. |
| **digan lo que digan** | whatever they say | Digan lo que digan, no cambiaré de opinión. |
| **quieras o no** | whether you like it or not | Quieras o no, es la verdad. |
| **que yo sepa** | as far as I know | Que yo sepa, no ha llegado. |

### 6. Subjunctive vs. Infinitive

When the subject of both clauses is the same, use the **infinitive** instead of the subjunctive:

- **Quiero ir.** (NOT ~~Quiero que yo vaya.~~)
- **Espero aprobar.** (NOT ~~Espero que yo apruebe.~~)

But when subjects differ:
- **Quiero que vayas.** — I want you to go.
- **Espero que apruebes.** — I hope you pass.
key_points: Aunque + subjunctive = hypothetical concession; aunque + indicative = known fact
Relative clauses take subjunctive when the antecedent is indefinite, nonexistent, or hypothetical
Negated certainty expressions (no creo que, no es cierto que) trigger the subjunctive
Pluperfect subjunctive (hubiera + participle) is used for past counterfactuals
Fixed expressions like sea como sea, pase lo que pase always use the subjunctive

ch_gram_c1_02.title: Literary Tenses
ch_gram_c1_02.theory:
## Literary Tenses

Spanish has several verb tenses that are primarily found in **literary, journalistic, and formal written** contexts. While rarely used in everyday speech, recognizing and understanding them is essential at the C1 level.

### 1. Pretérito Anterior (Past Anterior)

Formed with the **preterite of haber + past participle**. It indicates an action completed immediately before another past action.

| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | hube hablado |
| tú | hubiste hablado |
| él/ella/usted | hubo hablado |
| nosotros/as | hubimos hablado |
| vosotros/as | hubisteis hablado |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | hubieron hablado |

**Usage**: Appears after temporal conjunctions like **cuando**, **apenas**, **en cuanto**, **tan pronto como**, **después de que**.

- **Apenas hubo terminado de hablar, todos aplaudieron.** — As soon as he had finished speaking, everyone applauded.
- **Cuando hubo llegado, comenzó la reunión.** — When he had arrived, the meeting began.

**Modern replacement**: In spoken Spanish, this is replaced by the pluperfect (había hablado) or simple preterite.

### 2. Futuro de Subjuntivo (Future Subjunctive)

Almost extinct in modern spoken Spanish, but found in legal texts, proverbs, and very formal writing.

| Person | -ar (hablar) | -er (comer) | -ir (vivir) |
|---|---|---|---|
| yo | hablare | comiere | viviere |
| tú | hablares | comieres | vivieres |
| él/ella/usted | hablare | comiere | viviere |
| nosotros/as | habláremos | comiéremos | viviéremos |
| vosotros/as | hablareis | comiereis | viviereis |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | hablaren | comieren | vivieren |

**Note**: The stem is the same as the imperfect subjunctive (3rd person plural preterite minus -ron).

**Usage in proverbs**:
- **Donde fueres, haz lo que vieres.** — When in Rome, do as the Romans do. (Lit: Wherever you go, do what you see.)
- **Sea lo que fuere.** — Be that as it may.

**Usage in legal texts**:
- **Si el arrendatario no pagare la renta...** — If the tenant fails to pay the rent...
- **Quien infringiere esta ley será sancionado.** — Whoever breaks this law shall be sanctioned.

### 3. Future Perfect Subjunctive

Formed with **future subjunctive of haber + past participle**. Extremely rare, found only in the most archaic legal language.

- **Si hubiere terminado el plazo...** — If the deadline shall have expired...

### 4. The Literary Imperfect Subjunctive in -se

While both **-ra** and **-se** forms exist for the imperfect subjunctive, the **-se** form is considered more literary/formal:

| -ra form | -se form |
|---|---|
| hablara | hablase |
| comiera | comiese |
| viviera | viviese |

Both are interchangeable in most contexts, but **-se** is preferred in formal writing:
- **Si tuviese más tiempo, leería más.** — If I had more time, I would read more.

**Exception**: Only the **-ra** form can replace the conditional in literary style:
- **Quisiera hablar contigo.** (= Querría hablar contigo.) — I would like to talk to you.
- ~~Quisiese hablar contigo.~~ (NOT valid)

### 5. Preterite for Pluperfect (Literary Style)

In literary prose, the imperfect subjunctive **-ra** form sometimes replaces the pluperfect indicative:
- **La carta que escribiera (= había escrito) años atrás...** — The letter he had written years before...
key_points: The pretérito anterior (hubo hablado) indicates an action immediately before another past action; replaced by pluperfect in speech
The future subjunctive (hablare, comiere) survives only in legal texts and proverbs
The -se imperfect subjunctive (hablase) is more literary than the -ra form (hablara)
Only the -ra form can substitute the conditional (quisiera = querría), never -se
In literary prose, the -ra form can replace the pluperfect indicative (escribiera = había escrito)

ch_gram_c1_03.title: Complex Conditionals
ch_gram_c1_03.theory:
## Complex Conditionals

At C1 level, you must master all conditional structures, including mixed conditionals and alternative forms that go beyond the three basic types.

### Review of Standard Conditional Types

| Type | Si clause | Main clause | Example |
|---|---|---|---|
| Real (Type 1) | Present indicative | Future / Present / Imperative | Si llueve, no saldremos. |
| Hypothetical (Type 2) | Imperfect subjunctive | Conditional | Si tuviera dinero, viajaría. |
| Counterfactual (Type 3) | Pluperfect subjunctive | Conditional perfect | Si hubiera estudiado, habría aprobado. |

### Mixed Conditionals

Mixed conditionals combine elements from different types when the time frames of the condition and the result differ.

**Past condition → Present result**:
- **Si hubiera aceptado ese trabajo, ahora viviría en Madrid.** — If I had accepted that job, I would now be living in Madrid.
- **Si no hubieras comido tanto anoche, no te sentirías mal ahora.** — If you hadn't eaten so much last night, you wouldn't feel bad now.

**Present condition → Past result**:
- **Si fueras más organizado, habrías terminado a tiempo.** — If you were more organized, you would have finished on time.
- **Si no tuviera miedo a volar, habría ido a Japón.** — If I weren't afraid of flying, I would have gone to Japan.

### Alternative Conditional Structures

#### De + Infinitive (Formal/Literary)
Replaces **si + subjunctive** in formal or literary style:

- **De haberlo sabido, no habría venido.** — Had I known, I wouldn't have come. (= Si lo hubiera sabido...)
- **De ser posible, lo haría.** — Were it possible, I would do it. (= Si fuera posible...)
- **De no llegar a tiempo, avisadme.** — Should you not arrive on time, let me know.

#### Con que + Subjunctive
Means "as long as" or "provided that":
- **Con que estudies un poco, aprobarás.** — As long as you study a bit, you'll pass.

#### A no ser que / A menos que + Subjunctive
Means "unless":
- **Iré, a no ser que llueva.** — I'll go, unless it rains.
- **No lo terminaremos a menos que nos ayuden.** — We won't finish it unless they help us.

#### Como + Subjunctive (Warning/Threat)
- **Como no vengas, me enfadaré.** — If you don't come, I'll get angry.
- **Como vuelvas a llegar tarde, te despiden.** — If you're late again, they'll fire you.

#### Siempre que / Siempre y cuando + Subjunctive
Means "provided that / as long as":
- **Te ayudo siempre y cuando me lo pidas con educación.** — I'll help you as long as you ask me politely.

### Conditional Without "Si"

Several constructions express conditions without using **si**:

| Structure | Example | Translation |
|---|---|---|
| Yo que tú / Yo en tu lugar | Yo que tú, aceptaría la oferta. | If I were you, I'd accept the offer. |
| De no ser por | De no ser por ti, no habría aprobado. | If it weren't for you, I wouldn't have passed. |
| En caso de que + subj. | En caso de que necesites algo, llámame. | In case you need something, call me. |
| A condición de que + subj. | Lo haré a condición de que me pagues. | I'll do it on the condition that you pay me. |
key_points: Mixed conditionals combine different time frames: past condition + present result, or present condition + past result
De + infinitive replaces si + subjunctive in formal/literary style (De haberlo sabido = Si lo hubiera sabido)
Como + subjunctive expresses warnings or threats (Como no vengas, me enfadaré)
Siempre y cuando, a condición de que, con que all mean 'provided that' and take subjunctive
Yo que tú / Yo en tu lugar express hypothetical advice without using si

ch_gram_c1_04.title: Advanced Discourse Markers
ch_gram_c1_04.theory:
## Advanced Discourse Markers

Discourse markers (marcadores discursivos) are words and phrases that organize, connect, and structure speech and writing. At C1 level, mastering these is essential for producing coherent, well-structured arguments in both spoken and written Spanish.

### 1. Structuring Discourse

#### Opening / Introducing a Topic
| Marker | Usage |
|---|---|
| **En primer lugar** | In the first place |
| **Para empezar / Para comenzar** | To begin with |
| **Ante todo** | Above all / First of all |
| **En lo que respecta a** | With regard to |
| **En cuanto a** | As for / Regarding |
| **Por lo que se refiere a** | As far as ... is concerned |

#### Continuing / Adding Information
| Marker | Usage |
|---|---|
| **Además** | Furthermore / Moreover |
| **Asimismo / Del mismo modo** | Likewise / In the same way |
| **Por otra parte / Por otro lado** | On the other hand |
| **A su vez** | In turn |
| **Cabe destacar que** | It is worth noting that |
| **Es preciso señalar que** | It must be pointed out that |
| **No solo... sino también** | Not only... but also |

#### Concluding
| Marker | Usage |
|---|---|
| **En conclusión / En resumen** | In conclusion / In summary |
| **En definitiva** | Ultimately / In short |
| **A fin de cuentas** | At the end of the day |
| **En última instancia** | As a last resort / Ultimately |
| **Para concluir / Para finalizar** | To conclude / To finish |
| **Todo lo anterior demuestra que** | All of the above demonstrates that |

### 2. Expressing Contrast and Concession

| Marker | Usage | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **No obstante** | Nevertheless | Es caro. No obstante, merece la pena. |
| **Sin embargo** | However | Estudié mucho. Sin embargo, suspendí. |
| **Ahora bien** | Now then / However | Acepto tu propuesta. Ahora bien, con condiciones. |
| **Con todo (y con eso)** | Even so / Despite everything | Con todo, sigo pensando lo mismo. |
| **A pesar de todo** | Despite everything | A pesar de todo, no se rindió. |
| **Si bien** | Although / Even though | Si bien es difícil, no es imposible. |
| **Aun así** | Even so | Estaba cansado. Aun así, siguió trabajando. |

### 3. Expressing Cause and Consequence

| Marker | Usage |
|---|---|
| **Dado que / Ya que** | Given that / Since |
| **Puesto que** | Since / Given that |
| **De ahí que + subjunctive** | Hence / That is why |
| **Por consiguiente / Por lo tanto** | Therefore / Consequently |
| **De modo que / De manera que** | So that / In such a way that |
| **En consecuencia** | As a consequence |
| **A raíz de** | As a result of |

### 4. Reformulating and Clarifying

| Marker | Usage |
|---|---|
| **Es decir / O sea** | That is to say / In other words |
| **Dicho de otro modo** | Put another way |
| **En otras palabras** | In other words |
| **A saber** | Namely |
| **Mejor dicho** | Rather / More precisely |
| **Más concretamente** | More specifically |

### 5. Expressing Opinion

| Marker | Usage |
|---|---|
| **A mi juicio / A mi parecer** | In my judgment / In my opinion |
| **Desde mi punto de vista** | From my point of view |
| **En mi opinión** | In my opinion |
| **Considero que** | I consider that |
| **Cabe señalar que** | It should be noted that |
| **A mi modo de ver** | As I see it |
key_points: Use structuring markers (en primer lugar, además, en conclusión) to organize arguments clearly
Contrast markers (no obstante, sin embargo, ahora bien, si bien) show sophisticated argumentation
Cause/consequence markers (dado que, de ahí que + subjunctive, por consiguiente) connect reasoning
Reformulation markers (es decir, dicho de otro modo, mejor dicho) clarify and rephrase ideas
Opinion markers (a mi juicio, desde mi punto de vista) introduce personal perspectives formally

ch_gram_c1_05.title: Register Shifts
ch_gram_c1_05.theory:
## Register Shifts in Spanish

Register refers to the level of formality in language. At C1 level, you must be able to identify and switch between different registers depending on the social context, audience, and purpose.

### The Main Registers

| Register | Context | Characteristics |
|---|---|---|
| **Formal/Culto** | Academic, legal, professional | Complex syntax, specialized vocabulary, subjunctive, usted/ustedes |
| **Estándar** | News, education, general writing | Correct grammar, neutral vocabulary, accessible |
| **Coloquial** | Friends, family, everyday life | Colloquialisms, idioms, tú/vosotros, contractions |
| **Vulgar** | Very informal, slang-heavy | Slang, taboo words, grammatical shortcuts |

### Formal vs. Informal Equivalents

| Formal | Informal | Meaning |
|---|---|---|
| **realizar** | hacer | to do/carry out |
| **efectuar** | hacer | to carry out |
| **adquirir** | comprar | to acquire/buy |
| **residir** | vivir | to reside/live |
| **fallecer** | morir/morirse | to pass away/die |
| **finalizar** | terminar/acabar | to finalize/finish |
| **solicitar** | pedir | to request/ask for |
| **requerir** | necesitar | to require/need |
| **comunicar** | decir/contar | to communicate/tell |
| **proceder a** | empezar a | to proceed to/start |

### Address Forms and Register

| Register | Spain | Latin America |
|---|---|---|
| Formal singular | **usted** + 3rd person | **usted** + 3rd person |
| Informal singular | **tú** + 2nd person | **tú** / **vos** (varies by country) |
| Formal plural | **ustedes** + 3rd person | **ustedes** + 3rd person |
| Informal plural | **vosotros/as** + 2nd pl. | **ustedes** + 3rd person |

### Grammatical Features by Register

**Formal register tends to use**:
- Passive voice: **El informe fue presentado por el director.**
- Impersonal constructions: **Se ruega silencio.** / **Cabe mencionar que...**
- Subjunctive mood more frequently
- Nominalization: **la realización del proyecto** (instead of "hacer el proyecto")
- Longer, complex sentences with subordinate clauses

**Informal register tends to use**:
- Active voice: **El director presentó el informe.**
- Direct constructions: **¡Silencio!** / **Hay que decir que...**
- Indicative where subjunctive might be expected
- Verbs instead of nouns: **hacer el proyecto**
- Shorter, simpler sentences; sentence fragments

### Register Shift Examples

**Formal letter**:
> Estimado Sr. García: Le escribo para comunicarle que su solicitud ha sido aprobada. Le rogamos que se presente en nuestras oficinas a la mayor brevedad posible.

**Informal message**:
> ¡Ey, García! Te escribo para decirte que tu solicitud ha sido aprobada. Pásate por la oficina cuando puedas.

**Academic writing**:
> Los resultados obtenidos ponen de manifiesto la existencia de una correlación significativa entre ambas variables.

**Casual explanation**:
> Los resultados muestran que las dos cosas están relacionadas.

### Common Mistakes with Register

- Using **tú** in formal emails or with strangers in professional contexts
- Mixing registers within the same text (e.g., formal introduction with colloquial body)
- Using slang in academic or professional writing
- Being overly formal in casual conversation (sounds unnatural or distant)
key_points: Spanish has four main registers: formal/culto, estándar, coloquial, and vulgar
Formal vocabulary (realizar, adquirir, fallecer) differs significantly from informal (hacer, comprar, morir)
Formal register favors passive voice, impersonal constructions, subjunctive, and nominalization
Address forms (usted/tú/vos/vosotros) are key register markers that vary by region
Mixing registers within the same text is a common mistake to avoid

ch_gram_c1_06.title: Advanced Verbal Periphrasis
ch_gram_c1_06.theory:
## Advanced Verbal Periphrasis

Verbal periphrasis (perífrasis verbales) consists of a **conjugated auxiliary verb + linking element (preposition, conjunction, or nothing) + infinitive/gerund/participle**. At C1 level, you must master a wide range of these constructions, which convey aspectual nuances impossible with simple tenses.

### 1. Infinitive Periphrases

#### Beginning / Inchoative Aspect
| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **ponerse a + inf.** | to start to (sudden) | Se puso a llover de repente. |
| **echarse a + inf.** | to burst into (sudden) | Se echó a reír sin motivo. |
| **romper a + inf.** | to burst into (sudden, emotional) | Rompió a llorar al oír la noticia. |
| **liarse a + inf.** | to start doing (colloquial, prolonged) | Se liaron a discutir y no pararon. |
| **meterse a + inf.** | to start doing (without expertise) | Se metió a arreglar el coche y lo estropeó. |

#### Repetitive / Reiterative Aspect
| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **volver a + inf.** | to do again | Volvió a llamar tres veces. |
| **insistir en + inf.** | to insist on doing | Insistió en pagar la cuenta. |

#### Terminative Aspect
| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **dejar de + inf.** | to stop doing | Dejó de fumar hace un año. |
| **acabar de + inf.** | to have just done | Acabo de llegar a casa. |
| **terminar de + inf.** | to finish doing | Terminé de leer el libro anoche. |
| **llegar a + inf.** | to manage to / to go as far as | Llegó a ganar tres premios. |
| **acabar por + inf.** | to end up doing | Acabó por aceptar la oferta. |
| **terminar por + inf.** | to end up doing | Terminó por darme la razón. |

#### Obligation and Approximation
| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **haber de + inf.** | to be supposed to / must (literary) | Has de saber que no estoy de acuerdo. |
| **venir a + inf.** | to approximately / to turn out to | Viene a costar unos 50 euros. |
| **deber de + inf.** | to probably (conjecture) | Deben de ser las diez. |
| **deber + inf.** | to must (obligation) | Debes estudiar más. |

**Important**: **Deber + inf.** = obligation; **Deber de + inf.** = conjecture. This distinction is often blurred in spoken Spanish.

### 2. Gerund Periphrases

| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **estar + gerund** | to be doing (progressive) | Estoy estudiando español. |
| **seguir/continuar + gerund** | to continue doing | Sigue lloviendo desde ayer. |
| **llevar + time + gerund** | to have been doing for | Llevo tres años viviendo aquí. |
| **ir + gerund** | to gradually do | Los precios van subiendo poco a poco. |
| **andar + gerund** | to go around doing | Anda buscando trabajo por toda la ciudad. |
| **venir + gerund** | to have been doing (over time) | Vengo diciendo esto desde hace meses. |

### 3. Participle Periphrases

| Periphrasis | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **tener + participle** | to have (result, accumulated) | Tengo leídos tres capítulos. |
| **llevar + participle** | to have (accumulated, count) | Llevo escritas veinte páginas. |
| **dejar + participle** | to leave (in a state) | Dejó dicho que vendría mañana. |
| **quedar + participle** | to remain / be (resultant state) | El asunto quedó resuelto. |
| **dar por + participle** | to consider as | Doy por terminada la reunión. |
key_points: Inchoative periphrases (ponerse a, echarse a, romper a) express sudden beginnings with different nuances
Deber + inf. = obligation; deber de + inf. = conjecture — a key distinction at C1 level
Gerund periphrases (ir + gerund, andar + gerund, venir + gerund) express gradual, wandering, or ongoing actions
Llevar + time + gerund expresses duration (Llevo tres años viviendo aquí = I've been living here for three years)
Participle periphrases (tener + participle, dar por + participle) express accumulated or resultant states

ch_gram_c1_07.title: Ser/Estar Nuances
ch_gram_c1_07.theory:
## Ser/Estar Nuances

At C1 level, the ser/estar distinction goes far beyond the basic rules of "permanent vs. temporary." Many adjectives change meaning depending on which verb is used, and there are numerous exceptions and nuances.

### 1. Adjectives That Change Meaning

| Adjective | With SER | With ESTAR |
|---|---|---|
| **listo** | clever, smart | ready |
| **malo** | bad (character) | sick, ill |
| **bueno** | good (character) | tasty, attractive (colloq.) |
| **verde** | green (color) | unripe / risqué |
| **vivo** | lively, sharp | alive |
| **aburrido** | boring | bored |
| **interesado** | self-interested | interested |
| **despierto** | sharp, alert (character) | awake |
| **orgulloso** | proud (arrogant, trait) | proud (of something specific) |
| **atento** | attentive, thoughtful (trait) | attentive (at this moment) |
| **negro** | black (color) | furious, fed up (colloq.) |
| **rico** | rich (wealthy) | delicious |
| **seguro** | safe (inherently) | sure, certain |
| **cerrado** | narrow-minded | closed (physically) |
| **abierto** | open-minded | open (physically) |
| **católico** | Catholic | feeling well (neg.: no estar muy católico) |

### 2. Ser/Estar with Past Participles

- **SER + participle** = **passive voice** (action): La puerta **es abierta** por el portero. (The door is opened by the doorman.)
- **ESTAR + participle** = **resultant state**: La puerta **está abierta**. (The door is open.)

This distinction is critical:
- **El problema fue resuelto (por el equipo).** — The problem was solved (by the team). [passive action]
- **El problema está resuelto.** — The problem is solved. [current state]

### 3. Unexpected Uses of Estar

Some adjectives that seem "permanent" use **estar**:
- **Está muerto.** (He is dead.) — Not ser, even though death is permanent.
- **Está casado/divorciado/soltero.** — He is married/divorced/single.
- **Está lleno/vacío.** — It is full/empty.
- **Está roto.** — It is broken.
- **Está contento.** — He is happy/content.

The pattern: these describe **states resulting from a change**, not inherent qualities.

### 4. Unexpected Uses of Ser

Some situations that seem "temporary" use **ser**:
- **La fiesta es en mi casa.** — The party is at my house. [events use ser for location]
- **¿Qué hora es?** — What time is it? [time uses ser]
- **Es de noche.** — It's nighttime.
- **Es joven.** — She is young. [stage of life seen as defining characteristic]

### 5. Ser/Estar with Emotions and States

| With SER (trait) | With ESTAR (state) |
|---|---|
| Es feliz. (She is a happy person.) | Está feliz. (She is happy right now.) |
| Es nervioso. (He is a nervous person.) | Está nervioso. (He is nervous right now.) |
| Es tranquilo. (He is a calm person.) | Está tranquilo. (He is calm right now.) |
| Es triste. (She is a sad person.) | Está triste. (She is sad right now.) |

### 6. Stylistic and Emphatic Uses of Estar

Using **estar** where **ser** might be expected adds emphasis or surprise:
- **¡Qué guapa estás hoy!** — How pretty you look today! (emphasizes change/current impression)
- **Estás muy delgado.** — You're very thin. (implies recent change)
- **El café está muy caro últimamente.** — Coffee is very expensive lately. (implies it wasn't before)

### 7. Common Errors

- ~~Estoy profesor.~~ → **Soy profesor.** (profession = ser)
- ~~Es contento.~~ → **Está contento.** (contento always uses estar)
- ~~La reunión está en la sala 3.~~ → **La reunión es en la sala 3.** (events use ser for location)
key_points: Many adjectives change meaning with ser vs. estar (listo = clever/ready, malo = bad/sick, vivo = lively/alive)
Ser + participle = passive action; estar + participle = resultant state
States resulting from change use estar even if permanent (muerto, casado, roto)
Events use ser for location (La fiesta es en mi casa), not estar
Using estar where ser is expected adds emphasis or implies change (¡Qué guapa estás hoy!)

ch_gram_c1_08.title: Stylistic Inversions
ch_gram_c1_08.theory:
## Stylistic Inversions

Standard Spanish word order is **Subject-Verb-Object (SVO)**, but the language allows considerable flexibility. At C1 level, you should understand and use various inversions for emphasis, style, or grammatical necessity.

### 1. Verb-Subject Inversion (VS Order)

Spanish commonly inverts subject and verb in several contexts:

**After certain adverbs and adverbial phrases**:
- **Así lo decidió el juez.** — So the judge decided. (normal: El juez lo decidió así.)
- **Bien lo sabe el profesor.** — The teacher knows it well.
- **Quizá(s) tenga razón tu madre.** — Perhaps your mother is right.

**In questions** (standard inversion):
- **¿Viene Juan?** — Is Juan coming?
- **¿Dónde trabaja tu hermano?** — Where does your brother work?

**After direct speech**:
- **—No puedo más —dijo el soldado.** — 'I can't anymore,' said the soldier.
- **—Eso es imposible —respondió ella.** — 'That is impossible,' she replied.

**With intransitive verbs of existence/appearance**:
- **Llegó un paquete para ti.** — A package arrived for you.
- **Existen varias soluciones.** — Several solutions exist.
- **Surgió un problema inesperado.** — An unexpected problem arose.

### 2. Fronting (Topicalization)

Moving an element to the front of the sentence for emphasis or topic establishment:

**Object fronting**:
- **Eso ya lo sabía yo.** — That, I already knew. (Note the redundant pronoun **lo**)
- **A María la vi ayer.** — María, I saw her yesterday.
- **Dinero no me falta.** — Money I don't lack.

**Adjective fronting**:
- **Grande fue su sorpresa al verlo.** — Great was his surprise upon seeing it.
- **Difícil es encontrar a alguien así.** — Difficult it is to find someone like that.

**Adverbial fronting**:
- **En esta empresa nunca se ha trabajado tanto.** — In this company, people have never worked so hard.
- **Por eso mismo vinimos.** — For that very reason we came.

### 3. Mandatory Inversions

Some grammatical constructions require inversion:

**Relative clauses with subject relative pronoun**:
- **El libro que escribió mi abuelo...** — The book that my grandfather wrote... (VS preferred)

**After absolute participle constructions**:
- **Terminada la reunión, salieron todos.** — The meeting having ended, everyone left.
- **Dicho esto, procedamos al siguiente punto.** — Having said this, let us proceed to the next point.

**In exclamations**:
- **¡Qué bonita es esta ciudad!** — How beautiful this city is!
- **¡Cuánto ha crecido tu hijo!** — How your son has grown!

### 4. Literary Inversions

In literary and poetic Spanish, inversions are used for aesthetic effect:

- **Del salón en el ángulo oscuro...** (Bécquer) — In the dark corner of the room... (normal: En el ángulo oscuro del salón)
- **Verde que te quiero verde.** (García Lorca) — Green, how I want you green.

### 5. Hyperbaton

Extreme word-order alteration for poetic or rhetorical effect:

- **Con diez cañones por banda, viento en popa, a toda vela...** (Espronceda)
- **Volverán las oscuras golondrinas en tu balcón sus nidos a colgar.** (Bécquer) — The dark swallows will return to hang their nests on your balcony.
key_points: Verb-subject inversion is common after certain adverbs (así, quizás), in questions, and after direct speech
Fronting (topicalization) moves objects, adjectives, or adverbs to sentence-initial position for emphasis
Object fronting typically requires a redundant pronoun (A María la vi ayer)
Absolute participle constructions require inversion (Terminada la reunión, salieron todos)
Literary hyperbaton involves extreme reordering for poetic or rhetorical effect

ch_gram_c1_09.title: Advanced Conjunctions
ch_gram_c1_09.theory:
## Advanced Conjunctions

At C1 level, you must go beyond basic conjunctions (y, o, pero, porque) and master the full range of Spanish connectors and their grammatical requirements, particularly which conjunctions trigger the subjunctive.

### 1. Purpose Clauses (Finales)

All purpose conjunctions require the **subjunctive** when subjects differ:

| Conjunction | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **para que** | so that / in order that | Te lo explico para que lo entiendas. |
| **a fin de que** | in order that (formal) | Lo cambiaron a fin de que funcionara mejor. |
| **con el fin de que** | with the aim that | Hicimos cambios con el fin de que mejorara. |
| **con el objeto de que** | with the purpose that | Se reunieron con el objeto de que se llegara a un acuerdo. |
| **con vistas a que** | with a view to | Ahorramos con vistas a que nuestros hijos estudien. |
| **no sea que / no vaya a ser que** | lest / in case | Lleva paraguas, no sea que llueva. |

When the subject is the same, use **para / a fin de / con el fin de + infinitive**.

### 2. Concessive Clauses (Concesivas)

| Conjunction | Mood | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **aunque** | Ind. (fact) / Subj. (hypothetical) | Aunque llueve, salgo. / Aunque llueva, saldré. |
| **a pesar de que** | Ind. (fact) / Subj. (hypothetical) | A pesar de que está cansado, sigue. |
| **si bien** | Indicative | Si bien es caro, merece la pena. |
| **por más que** | Subjunctive | Por más que insistas, no cambiaré de opinión. |
| **por mucho que** | Subjunctive | Por mucho que estudie, no aprueba. |
| **aun cuando** | Subjunctive | Aun cuando tuviera dinero, no lo compraría. |
| **así + subjunctive** | Subjunctive (emphatic) | Así me lo pida de rodillas, no lo haré. |
| **y eso que** | Indicative (despite) | No vino, y eso que le avisamos. |

### 3. Temporal Clauses (Temporales)

**Subjunctive** when the action is future or hypothetical; **indicative** when habitual or past:

| Conjunction | Meaning | Example (Subj.) | Example (Ind.) |
|---|---|---|---|
| **cuando** | when | Cuando llegues, llámame. | Cuando llegó, me llamó. |
| **en cuanto / tan pronto como** | as soon as | En cuanto termine, te aviso. | En cuanto terminó, me avisó. |
| **antes de que** | before | Hazlo antes de que sea tarde. | (always subjunctive) |
| **después de que** | after | Saldremos después de que pare de llover. | Salimos después de que paró. |
| **hasta que** | until | Espera hasta que te llame. | Esperó hasta que lo llamé. |
| **mientras** | while/as long as | Mientras estés aquí, estás seguro. | Mientras estaba allí, llovía. |
| **una vez que** | once | Una vez que hayas terminado, avísame. | Una vez que terminó, me avisó. |

**Note**: **Antes de que** ALWAYS requires the subjunctive.

### 4. Causal Clauses (Causales)

| Conjunction | Meaning | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| **porque** | because | Most common |
| **ya que / puesto que / dado que** | since / given that | More formal |
| **como** | since / as | Always at the beginning of the sentence |
| **debido a que** | due to the fact that | Formal |
| **no porque + subj., sino porque** | not because... but because | No lo hago porque me obligan, sino porque quiero. |
| **por** | because of / for | + infinitive: Por llegar tarde, perdió el tren. |

### 5. Consecutive Clauses (Consecutivas)

| Structure | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **tan... que** | so... that | Es tan alto que no cabe por la puerta. |
| **tanto/a/os/as... que** | so much/many... that | Comió tanto que le dolió el estómago. |
| **tal... que** | such... that | Hizo tal esfuerzo que se desmayó. |
| **de ahí que + subjunctive** | hence | Estudió mucho, de ahí que aprobara. |
| **de modo/manera que** | so that / in such a way that | Lo explicó de manera que todos entendieran. |
| **así que / conque** | so / therefore | Ya has terminado, conque vámonos. |
key_points: Purpose conjunctions (para que, a fin de que, no sea que) always take the subjunctive when subjects differ
Concessive conjunctions: aunque takes indicative (fact) or subjunctive (hypothetical); por más que always takes subjunctive
Temporal conjunctions take subjunctive for future/hypothetical actions, indicative for past/habitual; antes de que always takes subjunctive
De ahí que + subjunctive is a formal consecutive connector meaning 'hence'
No porque + subjunctive, sino porque + indicative is used to reject one cause and state the real one

vocab_list.example_meaning: They modified the law in order to protect consumers.

ch_gram_c1_10.title: Clause Reduction & Participles
ch_gram_c1_10.theory:
## Clause Reduction and Participles

At C1 level, you should be able to use reduced clauses and participial constructions to make your writing more concise, formal, and sophisticated. These structures are common in academic, journalistic, and literary Spanish.

### 1. Absolute Participle Constructions

An absolute construction uses a **past participle + noun** (or pronoun) to replace an entire subordinate clause. The participle agrees in gender and number with the noun it modifies.

| Absolute Construction | Equivalent Full Clause |
|---|---|
| **Terminada la clase**, los alumnos salieron. | Cuando terminó la clase, los alumnos salieron. |
| **Resuelto el problema**, continuamos. | Después de que se resolvió el problema, continuamos. |
| **Dichas estas palabras**, se marchó. | Después de decir estas palabras, se marchó. |
| **Una vez firmado el contrato**, empezaremos. | Una vez que se firme el contrato, empezaremos. |
| **Vistas las pruebas**, el juez dictó sentencia. | Después de ver las pruebas, el juez dictó sentencia. |

### 2. Gerund Clauses as Adverbials

The gerund can replace various types of adverbial clauses:

**Temporal** (while / when):
- **Caminando por el parque, vi a un viejo amigo.** — While walking through the park, I saw an old friend.

**Causal** (since / because):
- **Sabiendo que no vendría, no le esperamos.** — Knowing he wouldn't come, we didn't wait for him.

**Conditional** (if):
- **Siendo sincero, te diré que no me gusta.** — If I'm honest, I'll tell you I don't like it.

**Concessive** (even though):
- **Aun teniendo razón, prefirió callarse.** — Even though he was right, he preferred to keep quiet.

**Manner** (by):
- **Estudiarás mejor organizando tu tiempo.** — You'll study better by organizing your time.

### 3. Infinitive Clauses

Infinitives can replace subordinate clauses in several ways:

**Temporal**:
- **Al llegar a casa, me llamó.** — Upon arriving home, he called me. (= Cuando llegó a casa...)
- **Antes de salir, cierra la puerta.** — Before leaving, close the door.
- **Después de comer, descansamos.** — After eating, we rested.

**Causal**:
- **Por no estudiar, suspendió.** — For not studying, he failed.
- **De tanto trabajar, enfermó.** — From working so much, he got sick.

**Conditional**:
- **De saberlo, no habría venido.** — Had I known, I wouldn't have come.

### 4. Adjective Clause Reduction

Relative clauses can sometimes be reduced to participial phrases:

| Full Relative Clause | Reduced Form |
|---|---|
| Los estudiantes **que fueron seleccionados** viajarán. | Los estudiantes **seleccionados** viajarán. |
| Las cartas **que fueron escritas** por Cervantes... | Las cartas **escritas** por Cervantes... |
| El informe **que fue presentado** ayer... | El informe **presentado** ayer... |

This is only possible with **passive relative clauses** (where the participle can replace "que + ser + participle").

### 5. Nominalized Infinitives

The infinitive can function as a noun (subject or object):

- **El saber no ocupa lugar.** — Knowledge takes up no space. (proverb)
- **Fumar es perjudicial para la salud.** — Smoking is harmful to health.
- **Me gusta el buen vivir.** — I enjoy the good life.

### 6. Style Considerations

- Absolute constructions and gerund clauses add **formality and conciseness**
- Overusing gerund clauses can make text feel heavy — use in moderation
- The gerund should NOT modify a noun directly: ~~una caja conteniendo libros~~ → **una caja que contiene libros**
- Exception: **agua hirviendo** (boiling water), **ardiendo** (burning) are accepted fixed forms
key_points: Absolute participle constructions (Terminada la clase, Resuelto el problema) replace subordinate clauses concisely
Gerund clauses can express temporal, causal, conditional, concessive, and manner meanings
Al + infinitive replaces temporal cuando clauses (Al llegar = Cuando llegó)
Passive relative clauses can be reduced to participle phrases (los estudiantes seleccionados = que fueron seleccionados)
The gerund should not directly modify a noun (use 'que contiene' not 'conteniendo') except in fixed forms like agua hirviendo

ch_gram_c1_11.title: Emphatic Constructions (Advanced)
ch_gram_c1_11.theory:
## Emphatic Constructions (Advanced)

Spanish has a rich arsenal of emphatic constructions that allow speakers and writers to highlight, intensify, or draw attention to specific elements. At C1 level, mastering these structures is essential for expressive and persuasive communication.

### 1. Cleft Sentences (Oraciones hendidas / escindidas)

Cleft sentences isolate one element for emphasis using **ser + element + relative clause**:

| Neutral | Cleft (Emphatic) |
|---|---|
| Juan rompió el vaso. | **Fue Juan quien** rompió el vaso. (It was Juan who broke the glass.) |
| Necesitamos más tiempo. | **Lo que necesitamos es** más tiempo. (What we need is more time.) |
| Me molesta su actitud. | **Lo que me molesta es** su actitud. (What bothers me is his attitude.) |
| Compré el libro aquí. | **Fue aquí donde** compré el libro. (It was here where I bought the book.) |

**Pseudo-clefts with lo que... es que**:
- **Lo que pasa es que no tengo dinero.** — The thing is, I don't have money.
- **Lo que quiero decir es que debemos actuar ya.** — What I mean is that we must act now.

### 2. Emphatic Pronoun Reduplication

Spanish uses redundant pronouns for emphasis:

- **A mí me parece bien.** — (To) ME, it seems fine. (A mí emphasizes the pronoun me)
- **A ti te lo dije.** — I told YOU. (A ti emphasizes te)
- **A ellos les importa mucho.** — To THEM it matters a lot.
- **Eso lo sé yo.** — I know THAT. (Fronted object with redundant lo)

### 3. Emphatic Use of Sí/Mismo

- **Sí que lo hizo.** — He DID do it. (Emphatic affirmation, countering a denial)
- **Yo sí que fui.** — I DID go.
- **Eso sí que es un problema.** — THAT is indeed a problem.
- **Yo mismo lo vi.** — I myself saw it.
- **Ella misma lo preparó.** — She herself prepared it.

### 4. Emphatic Negation

| Structure | Meaning | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **no... en absoluto** | not at all | No me gusta en absoluto. |
| **no... ni mucho menos** | not by any means | No es perfecto, ni mucho menos. |
| **no... para nada** | not at all | No estoy de acuerdo para nada. |
| **ni siquiera** | not even | Ni siquiera me saludó. |
| **de ninguna manera / de ningún modo** | in no way | De ninguna manera aceptaré eso. |
| **en/por ningún concepto** | under no circumstances | En ningún concepto debes firmar eso. |
| **jamás** | never (emphatic) | Jamás volveré a confiar en él. |
| **ni... ni** | neither... nor | Ni come ni deja comer. |

### 5. Intensifiers and Emphatic Adverbs

| Intensifier | Usage | Example |
|---|---|---|
| **sumamente** | extremely (formal) | Es sumamente importante. |
| **enormemente** | enormously | Me alegro enormemente. |
| **sobremanera** | exceedingly (literary) | Me preocupa sobremanera. |
| **de lo más + adj.** | really quite | Es de lo más interesante. |
| **la mar de + adj.** | really (colloquial) | Es la mar de simpático. |
| **pero que muy** | really very (emphatic) | Es pero que muy difícil. |
| **todo/a un/a + noun** | a real / a true | Es todo un caballero. |

### 6. Exclamatory Emphatic Structures

- **¡Vaya + noun!** — What a...! → **¡Vaya lío!** (What a mess!)
- **¡Menudo/a + noun!** — What a...! (ironic/emphatic) → **¡Menuda sorpresa!** (What a surprise!)
- **¡Lo + adj. + que + verb!** → **¡Lo difícil que es esto!** (How difficult this is!)
- **¡Cómo + verb!** → **¡Cómo llueve!** (How it rains!)
- **¡Si + future!** → **¡Si será tonto!** (How stupid can he be!)
key_points: Cleft sentences (Fue Juan quien..., Lo que necesitamos es...) isolate an element for emphasis
Redundant pronouns (A mí me parece, Eso lo sé yo) add emphasis to objects and indirect objects
Sí que + verb provides emphatic affirmation, often countering a previous denial
Emphatic negation structures (ni siquiera, de ninguna manera, en absoluto) intensify negation
Exclamatory structures like ¡Vaya + noun!, ¡Menudo/a + noun!, ¡Lo + adj + que...! express strong reactions

ch_gram_c1_12.title: Regional Variations
ch_gram_c1_12.theory:
## Regional Variations in Spanish Grammar

Spanish is spoken across over 20 countries, and grammatical variations between regions are significant. At C1 level, you should recognize and understand the major differences, even if you primarily use one variety.

### 1. Voseo

The use of **vos** instead of **tú** for the informal second person singular. Prevalent in Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay, and parts of Central America and Colombia.

| Tense | Tuteo (tú) | Voseo (vos) |
|---|---|---|
| Present indicative | tú hablas | vos hablás |
| Present indicative | tú comes | vos comés |
| Present indicative | tú vives | vos vivís |
| Imperative | habla (tú) | hablá (vos) |
| Imperative | come (tú) | comé (vos) |
| Imperative | vive (tú) | viví (vos) |
| Present subjunctive | que tú hables | que vos hablés (River Plate) / hables (other regions) |

**Note**: In River Plate Spanish (Argentina/Uruguay), voseo affects present indicative, imperative, and sometimes present subjunctive. In other regions (e.g., Chile, Colombia), voseo may only affect some tenses.

**Examples**:
- **¿Vos sabés dónde queda?** — Do you know where it is? (Argentina)
- **Sentate acá.** — Sit down here. (vos imperative)
- **Tú sabes / Vos sabés** — You know

### 2. Ustedes vs. Vosotros

| | Spain | Latin America |
|---|---|---|
| Informal plural | **vosotros/as** habláis | **ustedes** hablan |
| Formal plural | **ustedes** hablan | **ustedes** hablan |

In Latin America, **vosotros** is not used at all. **Ustedes** serves for both formal and informal plural.

### 3. Leísmo, Laísmo, and Loísmo

**Standard system** (most of Latin America and southern Spain):
- **lo/la** = direct object (person or thing)
- **le** = indirect object

**Leísmo** (accepted for masculine persons in central Spain by RAE):
- **Le vi ayer.** (instead of Lo vi ayer.) — I saw him yesterday.

**Laísmo** (NOT accepted by RAE, but common in Madrid/central Spain):
- **La dije que viniera.** (instead of Le dije...) — I told her to come.

**Loísmo** (NOT accepted, very dialectal):
- **Lo dije que viniera.** (instead of Le dije...) — I told him to come.

### 4. Pretérito Perfecto vs. Pretérito Indefinido

| | Spain (much of Peninsular) | Latin America / Canary Islands |
|---|---|---|
| Recent past | **He comido** hoy. (I have eaten today.) | **Comí** hoy. (I ate today.) |
| Completed past | **Comí** ayer. (I ate yesterday.) | **Comí** ayer. |

In most of Latin America and the Canary Islands, the **pretérito indefinido** (simple past) is preferred even for recent actions, while peninsular Spanish often uses the **pretérito perfecto** (present perfect) for events on the same day or with current relevance.

### 5. Diminutives and Augmentatives by Region

| Region | Common Diminutive | Example |
|---|---|---|
| Mexico | **-ito/a** (very frequent) | ahorita, tantito, cerquita |
| Colombia | **-ito/a** with affection | pueblito, tierrita |
| Argentina | **-ito/a** | momentito, poquito |
| Spain | **-ito/a, -illo/a** | pueblecito, pequeñillo |
| Guatemala, Costa Rica | **-tico/a** | momentico, chiquitico |
| Cuba, Caribbean | **-ico/a** | ratico, momentico |

### 6. Other Notable Variations

**Dequeísmo and Queísmo**:
- **Dequeísmo**: Incorrectly adding "de" before "que" → ~~Pienso de que~~ (should be: Pienso que)
- **Queísmo**: Incorrectly omitting "de" before "que" → ~~Me alegro que~~ (should be: Me alegro de que)

**Use of acá/allá (Latin America) vs. aquí/allí (Spain)**:
- Latin America tends to prefer **acá** and **allá** in everyday speech.

**Verb + pronoun placement**:
- In some Latin American regions: **Me la voy a comprar.** (proclisis common)
- In Spain more commonly: **Voy a comprármela.** (enclisis with infinitive)
key_points: Voseo (vos hablás, comé, viví) is standard in Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay, and parts of Central America
Latin America uses ustedes for both formal and informal plural; Spain uses vosotros for informal plural
Leísmo (le instead of lo for masculine persons) is accepted by RAE; laísmo and loísmo are not
Latin America prefers pretérito indefinido for recent past; peninsular Spain uses pretérito perfecto
Regional variations include diminutive forms (-tico in Costa Rica/Guatemala), dequeísmo/queísmo, and acá/allá preferences
